headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] .Certain statements made during this conference will be forward-looking statements that inv
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] .
Certain statements made during this conference will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future facts -- events will not affect their accuracy. More information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Qs, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's website. The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them, either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Ferriola, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. We appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our other executive vice pres
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. We appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our other executive vice presidents: Jim Darsey, Ladd Hall, Ray Napolitan, Joe Stratman, Dave Sumoski, and Chad Utermark. 
The leadership team in Charlotte would like to thank everyone on our Nucor-Paris deal, David J. Joseph, Duferdofin, NuMit Steel Technologies and Skyline Steel teams for a job well done in the second quarter. Taking advantage of our unrivaled competitive position and our highly flexible business model, you are positioning Nucor to thrive today, and most importantly, in the years ahead. Thank you. 
CFO, Jim Frias, will now review Nucor's second quarter performance and financial position. Following those comments, I will update you on the execution of our strategy of long-term profitable growth. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Second quarter of 2016 earnings of $0.73 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.70 per diluted share. This performance represents significant improvement over first quarter 2016 earnings of $0.22 per diluted share and y
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Second quarter of 2016 earnings of $0.73 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.70 per diluted share. This performance represents significant improvement over first quarter 2016 earnings of $0.22 per diluted share and year-ago segment quarter earnings of $0.39 per diluted share. 
Second quarter results included a LIFO charge of $19 million, which was in line with our guidance. This compared with the first quarter of 2016 charge of $28 million and a year-ago second quarter credit of $96 million. Our steel mills segment was a primary driver of our second quarter profit improvement with the largest gains at our sheet mills. Quarter-over-quarter profit growth was also achieved at our plate and bar mill. Nucor's Steelmaking Operations benefited from both volume growth and higher metal margins. Second quarter total steel mill shipments increased 5% over the first quarter of 2016. Our overall steel mill metal margin expanded by $16 per ton in the second quarter compared to the first quarter. Our downstream products segment also delivered strong earnings growth in second quarter from the first quarter and 2015 second quarter levels. Nucor's steel products business benefits from our market leadership positions and our diversified product portfolio. The strength at Nucor's downstream products business model allows us to profitably leverage our modest improvement in nonresidential construction markets. 
Performance at our raw materials segment also improved in the second quarter compared to the first quarter. The David J. Joseph Company scrap brokerage and scrap processing business were solidly profitable in the second quarter. The improvements at DJJ's recycling business were threefold. First, scrap pricing improved. Second, utilization and volume flows increased to support our steel mills increased production. Third, our scrap processing team has done excellent work achieving efficiency improvements and cost reductions throughout their operations. 
Our direct reduced iron, or DRI, facilities achieved significant quarter-over-quarter improvement in their financial performance. At the same time, our raw materials teams continue to enhance Nucor's overall profitability by working with our steel mills to optimize the cost of their iron units. Maintaining Nucor's position as the low-cost producer across our raw materials, steelmaking and steel products businesses is an unrelenting focus for all of our teams. 
Our tax rate can be confusing due to the impact of profits from noncontrolling interests. Excluding profits belonging to our business partners, the effective tax rate was approximately 32.5% for the second quarter of 2016. 
Nucor's financial position remains strong. Our gross debt-to-capital ratio was 35% at the close of the second quarter. Cash and short-term investments totaled approximately $2.3 billion, which compares with total debt outstanding of $4.4 billion. Nucor's strong liquidity position also includes our $1.5 billion unsecured revolving credit facility, which remains undrawn. The facility does not mature until 2021. 
Nucor is the only North-American-headquartered steel producer to hold an investment-grade credit rating. Our capital allocation priorities are clear. They have been consistently and effectively practiced over Nucor's entire history. Our first priority is to invest for profitable, long-term growth that delivers attractive returns on our invested capital. Our second priority is to provide our shareholders with cash dividends that are consistent with our success in growing Nucor's earnings. Our third priority is to opportunistically repurchase our stock when our cash position is strong and attractively priced growth opportunities are limited. 
We expect further strong improvement in earnings in the third quarter of 2016. The steel mills segment will benefit from contract pricing resets in the third quarter at our sheet mills. Contracts currently represent about 60% of Nucor's sheet mill volume. The steel products segment continues to experience positive earnings momentum. Particularly strong profit growth is being realized at the rebar fabrication and metal buildings businesses. All of our steel products teams are doing excellent work in managing the challenge of this year's rising steel price environment. The raw materials segment's performance is expected to achieve profitability in the third quarter of 2016. Our DRI facilities will be profitable, benefiting from improved product pricing, lower iron ore costs and continued gains and and yield performance. Our Trinidad and Louisiana plants are now consistently performing at what we believe to be world-class conversion cost levels. Our David J. Joseph Company scrap position should also benefit from the more favorable scrap pricing environment that has been in place since the spring of this year. We are confident that Nucor's significant competitive advantages and highly adaptable business model will allow our team to continue to execute our proven strategies for delivering profitable long-term growth and attractive returns to Nucor's shareholders. 
We appreciate your interest in our company. John?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Nucor's strategy for profitable growth is simple, flexible and focused. It is one that we've implemented for more than 5 decades. Nucor capitalizes on its unrivaled position of strength to gain profitable market share in our core businesses o
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Nucor's strategy for profitable growth is simple, flexible and focused. It is one that we've implemented for more than 5 decades. Nucor capitalizes on its unrivaled position of strength to gain profitable market share in our core businesses of steel and steel products. We are doing this by taking care of our customers. Delivering an unrivaled value proposition for our customers is how we earn attractive returns on our shareholders' valuable capital. Anchoring our strategy are Nucor's 5 drivers to profitable growth. They are: strengthen our position as a low-cost producer; achieve market leadership positions in every product line in our portfolio; continue to move up the value chain by expanding our capabilities to produce higher-quality, higher-margin, more import-resistant products; expand and leverage our downstream channels to the market to increase our steel mills' baseload volume, especially in weak markets; and achieve commercial excellence to complement our traditional operational strength. Our strategy for profitable growth is working. It is paying off today with the potential for much larger returns in the future. 
I will now update you on highlights of our recent progress. Nucor's steel mill volume growth in 2016 highlights our success in gaining profitable market share. For the first 6 months of 2016, our steel mill production increased 13% over the year-ago period. That compared with the U.S. steel industry's decrease of approximately 1% over the same period. This profitable growth did not just happen. It is the result of our highly flexible and low-cost production capabilities, our unrivaled product breadth and diversity, our investments that have allowed us to move up the value chain, our execution of our channel-to-market strategy, and most importantly, the hard work done by my more than 23,000 Nucor teammates. 
The best news is that we are far from finished executing our strategy. There's a lot more to come. We are adding cylinders to Nucor's engine for generating higher highs and higher lows in earnings and cash flow. As always, our objective is delivering attractive returns on our shareholders' valuable capital. 
Demand is growing for our Berkeley County, South Carolina sheet mills new, wide-light products. After shipping approximately 160,000 tons of wide-light products in 2015, Berkeley is on track to ship about 270,000 tons in 2016. That's up from their earlier target of 240,000 tons for this year. This wide-light product capability is allowing us to produce more grades of advanced high-strength steels for the automotive market. We are also using wide-light products to gain share in a number of other targeted markets, ranging from appliance to motor lamination to welding wire. 
Our Nucor-Yamato joint venture is continuing to expand its value-added structural steel product portfolio. Last year, Nucor-Yamato began shipping its wider sheet piling sections. These wider sections are lighter and stronger, covering more area at a lower installed cost. Prior to our entry, this market had been largely served by imports. Nucor-Yamato is marketing these sections through our piling distribution business, Skyline Steel. Nucor-Yamato's NZ sheet piling sections are already enjoying strong marketplace success. During the first half of 2016, shipments on the new wide sheet piles have more than tripled to over 19,000 tons. 2 of the 4 wider sheet piling product groups have now been commercialized. The 2 other groups will enter production by the end of this year. Nucor-Yamato's goal over the next several years is to grow our wider sheet piling annual volume to 100,000 tons. Nucor-Yamato is nearing completion of another growth initiative, expanding its value-added structural steel product offerings. A $75 million project, adding Quench and Self-Tempering Technology, will position Nucor-Yamato, as the sole North American producer of high-strength, low-alloy beams. Initial trial production is scheduled to start in September. Trials across the entire range of high-strength, low-alloy beams are expected to be completed by the end of next year's first quarter. These beams allow the use of lighter foot weights, which reduces the weight and cost for the builder. That enhances the competitiveness of steel versus concrete and wood. Nucor-Yamato's target over the next several years is to grow its high-strength, low-alloy beam annual volume to 50,000 tons. 
During the second quarter, our Memphis SBQ bar mill completed installation of its heat-treating equipment and began running trials on new value-added products. This expands our capabilities to include Quench and Tempering as well as annealing of bars from 2.5 inches to 12 inches in diameter. I would like to thank our SBQ bar mill and downstream cold-finished bar teams for their excellent work, maintaining profitability in adverse market conditions, while also building for future growth with their numerous initiatives moving us up the value chain. 
During the second quarter, our Vulcraft/Verco joist and decking business announced plans to expand its geographical reach into Canada. Vulcraft Canada, our first Vulcraft facility in Canada, will be located near Hamilton, Ontario. It will manufacturing steel joists, joist girders and decking. We expect to start producing deck by the end of this year with joist production starting in the first quarter of next year. 
Effective implementation of Nucor's vertical integration and channel-to-market strategy is a key competitive strength and an attractive growth platform for our company. In June, Nucor formed a 50-50 joint venture with JFE Steel of Japan to build and operate a facility to produce galvanized sheet steel for the growing Mexican automotive market. The plant will be strategically located in Central Mexico. It's expected to have a cost of about $270 million. Operations are expected to begin in the second half of 2019. Annual capacity will be approximately 400,000 tons of galvanized sheet steel. It's important to note that Nucor and JFE will each supply an equal amount of substrate to be processed at the facility. We are excited to begin what we expect to be a long-term partnership with JFE Steel, a premier supplier of high-quality automotive steels. 
Yesterday, we announced an agreement to acquire Joy Global's steel plate mill in Longview, Texas, for approximately $29 million. Annual capacity of that facility is about 180,000 tons. The mill produces specialty plate products ranging from 1 to 12 inches thick and up to 138 inches wide. Complementing our existing plate mills' product capability, reaching up to 3 inches thick and 120 inches wide, the Texas mill will enable Nucor to capture a growing share of niche value-added plate markets. We are confident our plate commercial team will be able to leverage this expanded product portfolio to grow our overall plate business. All of these investment projects have the same very simple objective: creating attractive long-term value for our customers, our teammates and our shareholders. 
That discipline drives every capital allocation decision we make at Nucor. Our disciplined approach to being effective stewards of our shareholders' capital also requires that our team tackles significant challenges to our business. To that end, Nucor continues to be proactive and aggressive in pursuing trade cases when and where it is appropriate. When foreign producers and governments break mutually agreed-upon laws governing trade, there must be meaningful consequences. Utilizing trade remedies is not protectionism. Trade enforcement is absolutely critical to drive the change towards a market-based system. A market-based system is one where efficiency and innovation determine which producers win and which producers lose. We are encouraged by recent actions taken by the U.S. government that paved the way for the imposition of much-needed antidumping and countervailing revenues in some products against some countries breaking U.S. and international trade laws. But there remains much more work to be done. As always, Nucor is up to the challenge and will continue fighting hard for free and fair trade. 
I would like to close my remarks by expressing my thanks to our teams at our DRI plants in Trinidad and Louisiana for what they have achieved for Nucor. Your facilities today produce the highest-quality and lowest-cost DRI in the world. Your hard work and perseverance are absolutely critical to our company's success in continuing to move up the value chain. Thank you, and please keep it going. 
We would now be happy to answer your questions.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Matthew Korn with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Matthew Korn with Barclays.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're all watching the import numbers carefully. I'm wondering, do your customers show any indication to you, an expectation, that they think availability from imported steel is going to meaningfully increase over the rest of this year?
componenttext: So we're all watching the import numbers carefully. I'm wondering, do your customers show any indication to you, an expectation, that they think availability from imported steel is going to meaningfully increase over the rest of this year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, the feedback that we get from our customers is that it's frankly the opposite. When our customers are telling us that when they look at the final landed price of the import offers, the difference is great enough to justify the risk. The other po
componenttext: Actually, the feedback that we get from our customers is that it's frankly the opposite. When our customers are telling us that when they look at the final landed price of the import offers, the difference is great enough to justify the risk. The other point that I would make is when you look at where we are in this -- where we are this year, customers buying imports today, placing the orders today, can't really expect the deliveries until sometime in mid -- somewhere -- it's either early fourth quarter or mid fourth quarter. And at that point, they've got to think about their year-end inventories. So I think there's a bit of a hesitation to do too much on ordering on the import side as a result of their concerns over their year-end inventories. And I also point out a little bit about -- there's some availability issues and the [indiscernible] that is available out there today, a lot of the results of the trade cases -- the successful prosecution of the trade cases, particularly in sheet and some other products. And also concern that our customers have over the other trade cases that are currently in process. So based on all of that information and from the feedback we're getting from our customers, we don't see that as a major concern at this time.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. It's very helpful. Let me follow up this way, if I could. On scrap, how do the flows to the shutters look so far this summer? When you look at the moving pieces, the export demand, or lack thereof, competition from keep, Chinese Semites, the highe
componenttext: Got it. It's very helpful. Let me follow up this way, if I could. On scrap, how do the flows to the shutters look so far this summer? When you look at the moving pieces, the export demand, or lack thereof, competition from keep, Chinese Semites, the higher utilization rates from you and the other AF produces, do you see much upside risk to scrap prices over the rest of the year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew, this is Joe Stratman. Let me take a shot at that. The flows have improved through the course of the year, as you might imagine. The increased demand from steel mills across the country raised prices. And with the price increases, flow followed in
componenttext: Matthew, this is Joe Stratman. Let me take a shot at that. The flows have improved through the course of the year, as you might imagine. The increased demand from steel mills across the country raised prices. And with the price increases, flow followed into the scrap yards, which is the normal trend. At this point, with the currency exchange, the strength of the U.S. dollar, the weakness in Europe, in other words, there's a lot of scrap available in Europe, and the Chinese billets moving around the world, the trade flows there, I don't see a lot of upside pressure on scrap. But similarly, the demand, the robust demand for domestic steel mills I think also keeps the demand side level. And that we've reached a pretty good point of supply and demand where we would view a lot of stability on the last half of the year on scrap pricing.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, I might add to that point, when you think about our DRI facilities and the leveling effect that has to our company, and frankly, for the industry, as well as some of the [indiscernible] imports that have been rolling into the country are also a stabi
componenttext: Joe, I might add to that point, when you think about our DRI facilities and the leveling effect that has to our company, and frankly, for the industry, as well as some of the [indiscernible] imports that have been rolling into the country are also a stabilizing factor.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, John. As I mentioned, the strength of the dollar and the supply available scrap in Europe, but also as John mentioned, pig iron from both Brazil and from Eastern Europe and Russia, the supply is pretty stable right now. And also as John answer
componenttext: Absolutely, John. As I mentioned, the strength of the dollar and the supply available scrap in Europe, but also as John mentioned, pig iron from both Brazil and from Eastern Europe and Russia, the supply is pretty stable right now. And also as John answered in the first part of your question, we think the demand outlook is also good and not negative in any way. So supply and demand of the supply side should keep stability there for a while, we think.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on trade. You've seen some success on the sheet side. And I was wondering, what are the timing if you wanted to do more incremental work on trade on the sheet and products? So one thing that kind of comes to mind is -- we saw results fro
componenttext: First question is on trade. You've seen some success on the sheet side. And I was wondering, what are the timing if you wanted to do more incremental work on trade on the sheet and products? So one thing that kind of comes to mind is -- we saw results from coated, some of the results from cold-rolled and some of the countries are getting similar duties, not many, but Taiwan, for example, included. And I think we'll probably see some cold-rolled results pretty soon. Maybe there'll be another hole or 2 there. For these types of countries, already hearing that maybe some of the Taiwan offers are back in the market again, now that we've gone after them and they kind of escaped, at least the certain line of cases, how long does the industry have to wait before they can go after them again, if they do start to pick up in the future? And then kind of the same question on countries that made key products that weren't named in the initial cases because maybe there weren't big suppliers of the U.S. market, but now that some other guys can't sell into the U.S. market, they're stepping up. And you're hearing some talk about cold-rolled coming in from Vietnam and maybe a couple of the European countries, numbers are starting to tick up a little bit. Is there anything preventing the U.S. industry from going after a fresh run of cases on the same product from different countries?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, to answer that question directly, the answer would be no. Certainly, if we've seen an uptick, and the uptick comes with product that is probably at dump levels, and we believe that there's a violation of our trade laws, then we certainly would go af
componenttext: Well, to answer that question directly, the answer would be no. Certainly, if we've seen an uptick, and the uptick comes with product that is probably at dump levels, and we believe that there's a violation of our trade laws, then we certainly would go after them, okay? No doubt about that. The other point that I would like to make to the question is when you mentioned about other countries stepping into supply such as Vietnam or some new suppliers, bear in mind that they are impacted and unqualified in many of these applications and they need to go through an extensive qualification period. They're taking a wider risk when you look at -- and frankly, the pricing that's coming in is as high from those countries. So when we combine the higher price with the increased risk with the last places where it can be applied because of the qualifications, we don't see that as much of a threat. But however, to your point, if we do see an uptick in it and we do see it coming in at dump prices or we see it coming in from countries that are receiving large subsidies from the government or in any way violating our trade and international trade laws, then we are certainly free to take action. On your point about moving to the smaller suppliers, bear in mind, that there's [indiscernible] to the fact that we were able to be so successful against the big boys, the big suppliers, the ones who bring in large binds of steel at incredibly dump prices. When you take that out of the equation, we certainly don't have any problem competing with products coming in at fair prices from other countries as long as they adhere to the trade laws.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then maybe just a quick one for Jim. Corporate expense was pretty high this quarter. I know it's very lumpy. Just wondering what might have been driving that. If we should expect that to return back to normal by next quarter?
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then maybe just a quick one for Jim. Corporate expense was pretty high this quarter. I know it's very lumpy. Just wondering what might have been driving that. If we should expect that to return back to normal by next quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the biggest driver in the year-to-date difference is LIFO. LIFO went from $112 million credit to a $46.5 million expense. It has about $160 million swing of the total difference of the 2 30, roughly. The next biggest driver is probably profit on int
componenttext: Well, the biggest driver in the year-to-date difference is LIFO. LIFO went from $112 million credit to a $46.5 million expense. It has about $160 million swing of the total difference of the 2 30, roughly. The next biggest driver is probably profit on intercompany sales. We always have some volume of intercompany inventory in our downstream businesses. And other steel mills having higher margins, we have to take a charge to write that inventory value down to its cost of production. And so there's a takeaway there from the profit in those steel mills segment. And then finally, we do have a significant part of our pay across the company, including our profit sharing for the retirement accounts of our workforce. That's driven our profitability [indiscernible] probably $25-ish million dollars of the difference is profit sharing and incentive comp being improved [indiscernible] we're making more money. It's a good thing. But more than that, number is changing, the happier our shareholders are.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Late September. Somewhere around late September. So we're looking really good on the cold-rolled and galvanized. On the hot-rolled side, we're seeing a little bit more pressure. But that being said, on the hot-rolled said, when we look at the service cent
componenttext: Late September. Somewhere around late September. So we're looking really good on the cold-rolled and galvanized. On the hot-rolled side, we're seeing a little bit more pressure. But that being said, on the hot-rolled said, when we look at the service center inventory levels, they're extremely low. And with the reduced imports and some of our competitors shutting down operations, we see reduction in supply. So -- although we've seen a slowdown in the order entry rate for hot-rolled, and it's a little bit more challenged in cold-rolled or gal, we still feel comfortable with where we are in the hot-rolled market.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. And then second question, just on sort of the M&A pipeline. It seems like there's definitely a hunt on for downstream acquisition in the industry. And I think one school of thought has been potentially trying to acquire pipe and tube a
componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then second question, just on sort of the M&A pipeline. It seems like there's definitely a hunt on for downstream acquisition in the industry. And I think one school of thought has been potentially trying to acquire pipe and tube assets to leverage the hot pan capacity that people have. Is that something that you guys would entertain? And can you just kind of talk to how robust your pipeline is right now for acquisitions?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we mentioned several times that part of our strategy is to enhance our channels to the market. And we've had a very successful track record of utilizing our downstream operations not only to get to the final customer as a channel to the market, but
componenttext: Well, we mentioned several times that part of our strategy is to enhance our channels to the market. And we've had a very successful track record of utilizing our downstream operations not only to get to the final customer as a channel to the market, but also it's very, very strong profit generators in their own right. So we're always open to that. I would and -- we're open to many opportunities. We are always out there looking for where we can invest our cash for -- in long-term profitable growth. So I'm not including anything. I'm not excluding anything. And I'm not going to comment anything in particular. But one area that we are focused on, and you'll hear more from us on how we continue to increase on our hot-rolled, since you mentioned specifically what we would do with our hot-rolled. We continue to invest in bringing our hot-rolled to our higher-quality level. Some of the work we're doing in galvanized today is investing to take it out of simply the pricing to the market and get it into high-quality downstream businesses. So general answer, we're interested in everything. We work hard at everything. You've heard us say that we have a very focused but flexible investment strategy, growth strategy. And we look at whatever comes along. We don't have any strong preferences to any particular downstream business.

componenttext: I Wanted to ask you a little bit more about your product mix, if we could drill down just looking at your data here. We were kind of surprised to see the structural number decline. And even though sheet number bounced a lot, I think it was discussed at 5 50 average is much lower than where the spot market's been, even just for HRC. And I know there's a lag. But are we missing something? Or is there another reason why the average sheet price is so much lower? Even looking at CRE numbers, I can't quite reconcile them. So I'm just wondering if you can give us a little more color.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you hit the nail in the head. When you talk about our contract pricing, we have a very large percentage of our sheet business under contract. And it does lag. And most people tend to just think about it as a single-month lag. But when you add in the
componenttext: Well, you hit the nail in the head. When you talk about our contract pricing, we have a very large percentage of our sheet business under contract. And it does lag. And most people tend to just think about it as a single-month lag. But when you add in the lead times that are involved, you have to really extend that out a little bit. So when it comes to your question about pricing on sheet, I would say that without a doubt, the issue there is a large percentage of contract pricing. We expect to have -- to pick that up in the third quarter. So we're looking forward to that happening. On the question about structural, we had a nice jump in our structural percentage from quarter-over-quarter last quarter. So it's not unusual for us to see a smaller jump quarter-over-quarter in the second quarter over first quarter. [indiscernible]

componenttext: Timna, this is Chad. This is just a comment. Overall demand for structural product year-over-year is up about 3% or 4%. Our Nucor shipments of steel is up about 15%. componenttext: Got you. Yes, in the last quarter I asked question. I'm going to ask the same one again, make it nice and easy for you. You're right at 2.4 million tons of sheet in the first quarter and you're at 2.5. So you did ramp up as we discussed. But I'm still perplexed as the answer then you said was 11.5 million to 12 million annualized tons is more normal and an annualized base is just still running at 10 million tons. So question is, do you have spare capacity to run more sheet in light of these tight market conditions?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a limited capacity certainly on cold-rolled and gal. I would say we have some capacity available on hot-rolled as we look out past the next couple of weeks. One of the other things -- Chad mentioned the issue on mix, and the same thing up on
componenttext: Well, we have a limited capacity certainly on cold-rolled and gal. I would say we have some capacity available on hot-rolled as we look out past the next couple of weeks. One of the other things -- Chad mentioned the issue on mix, and the same thing up on the side of hot-rolled. So as we continue to ship our mix higher and higher on the value-added, a lot of that product runs lower on our mills. And we can deduce less number of tons. The poster child example of that would be at our Berkeley mill with a wide-light product move into the advanced type strength steels that will produce a higher strength steel product that's a lot -- takes exit time, takes exit time in the back and degasser. And then of course, wondering though [indiscernible] gauges, it takes extra time to run through the mill. So it's basically a question of mix, more than anything else.

componenttextpreview: So you just [indiscernible] everybody in this room. [indiscernible] wondering which cell phone went off or whose phone that was. That's what all the trumping is about, everybody reached for the cell phones in their pockets. But -- so going back to your qu
componenttext: So you just [indiscernible] everybody in this room. [indiscernible] wondering which cell phone went off or whose phone that was. That's what all the trumping is about, everybody reached for the cell phones in their pockets. But -- so going back to your question about Big River steel coming online. Certainly, that will add supply. Are we concerned about it? Well, it's a competitor. That's a good thing. We've added had new competitors coming online in the past over the last several years. We deal with it. We're not afraid of competition. And I would say to you that, frankly, it's more than just equipment that comes online. You got to have the relationships with the customers. You got teammates who understand how to make the products. You have to -- we have advantages such as our diversity, advantage I believe we would have over them or other competitors is our vertical integration and our ability to take advantage of that vertical integration. So we'll -- they'll come online. We'll deal with them. And one of the things that is nice about having extra competition coming from the domestic source is they do play by the same rules as us and they can't cheat. And we like that. I'll take extra competition from U.S. supplier than an international one any day of the week.

componenttext: Excellent question. And you hope -- again, to get into the -- the nuts and bolts going to spend a lot of about the details, but the direct answer to your question is yes. We do keep that number constant. And that's something that we're evaluating right now as we look at how some others report the numbers. And we typically have the same number year after year after year so that we can compare ourselves quarter over quarter over quarter. Others are using the typical mixes or what they anticipate their product mix to be to -- for the quarter to generate a denominator and then, of course, capacity utilization.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would add, John, numbers in a nameplate number. They're usually higher than the nameplate number because at some point in time history going above the nameplate number. And so we typically report based on the peak we could achieve in an ideal circum
componenttext: And I would add, John, numbers in a nameplate number. They're usually higher than the nameplate number because at some point in time history going above the nameplate number. And so we typically report based on the peak we could achieve in an ideal circumstance for the perfect mix, not based on what the current market mix might be or other factors like that can [indiscernible]

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's absolutely correct. Frankly, we were really disappointed if we had a generated production what the nameplate said. Our goal is to exceed that at all times. Having said all of that, I will tell you that the other thing that comes into play here
componenttext: Yes, that's absolutely correct. Frankly, we were really disappointed if we had a generated production what the nameplate said. Our goal is to exceed that at all times. Having said all of that, I will tell you that the other thing that comes into play here is that, as I mentioned earlier in one of the other questions, mix is changing dramatically to higher quality, higher profitable products. As a result, they tend to run slower in our mills. So we are taking a look at evaluating just where we are with that during the next quarter and perhaps resetting those numbers at the end of the year. I don't think -- in fact, I'm sure we won't go change it quarter by quarter. We just don't think that's a fair way to represent our utilization, but we will evaluate where we are today based upon our new product mix that we are running the higher-quality, slower-running products in our mills.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joe Stratman. We certainly see it as an advantage. We do have an international reach through our brokerage team, our DJJ brokerage team. We can bring scrap in from virtually all over the world. And we can bring scrap substitutes from virtually all
componenttext: This is Joe Stratman. We certainly see it as an advantage. We do have an international reach through our brokerage team, our DJJ brokerage team. We can bring scrap in from virtually all over the world. And we can bring scrap substitutes from virtually all over the world. In the advantage clearly is it provides us a great deal of flexibility to use all the resources across the globe to get the most cost-effective source of raw material. So at times, it will be domestic scrap. At times, it will be international scrap substitute. So we certainly believe it's an advantage. And we certainly use it to our best advantage.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me say I refer to it is a little play company in Texas. I'm going to say it's a great, great play company in Texas. And I'm very glad that you asked this question because I wanted to take just a minute and to welcome all of our new teammates fro
componenttext: Well, let me say I refer to it is a little play company in Texas. I'm going to say it's a great, great play company in Texas. And I'm very glad that you asked this question because I wanted to take just a minute and to welcome all of our new teammates from Longview, Texas, into the Nucor family. So any of you who are listening to this call today, we're excited to have you on board. Welcome. I want to tell you, I was at the facility yesterday frankly to welcome everyone into the company and to roam around and walk around the facility. That's a great -- it's a great facility. We've added it at a very good price, okay? A very fat price. And we work it out. We've got about $161 a ton for a plate mill. And that's pretty good price. Why are we doing it? Well, there's a lot of good reasons. Number one, and Chad, you can jump if I miss anything. But number one, just from a sizing perspective, it really fills a void that we had in our portfolio. We want to be able to offer customers a full range of plate products. And currently today, we go up to -- I'm thinking I'm going to get this right, correct me if I'm not -- 3 inches in thickness and 128 inches in width. And with the facility in Longview, we call it Nucor Longview, okay, we'll be able to go up to 12 inches and, I believe, it's 138 inches in width. And beyond that, because they utilize what's known as the bottom forward Ingrid process, okay, you get extremely clean steels that allow us to sell into many, many high-quality, higher-margin applications. Military applications, applications, airplanes, or think they make great brackets for our -- for some of the airplane applications. The [indiscernible] marketing went into well, heavy equipment market they go into. In addition to production, they have an incredible heat-treating and annealing operation. If I have it correct, think it's 18 heat-treating facilities, they call them bottle -- up-bottom -- excuse me, bottom furnaces for heat treating. And I'm going to tell you what, I spent -- I've visited a couple of weeks ago. There again yesterday. I'll want you to know the great equipment they have but more importantly than any of that, they've got a great workforce, the culture's fantastic. It's with Nucor and if you can't tell by the time of [indiscernible] I'll tell you, I'm really excited to have them join the Nucor team.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Chad Utermark. Just to add on to what John said at the specialty products at this mill is capable of making into these valuable niche markets, more value-added markets we want to penetrate. I'd be remiss if I didn't mention that our current N
componenttext: Yes. This is Chad Utermark. Just to add on to what John said at the specialty products at this mill is capable of making into these valuable niche markets, more value-added markets we want to penetrate. I'd be remiss if I didn't mention that our current North American commercial footprint that we already have in place and this great relationship we had with plate customers all across United States, we're going to be able to bring this product to market very quickly. And like John said, I'm excited to have this asset. But more importantly, the team that's down there, what a great group of men and women we're excited about moving forward.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And ask about capital. Frankly, there was some capital that will put in there. It will be minor. As we get to know more about the business and we see new applications, we might be adding something down the road. But now looking at any major influx. They'v
componenttext: And ask about capital. Frankly, there was some capital that will put in there. It will be minor. As we get to know more about the business and we see new applications, we might be adding something down the road. But now looking at any major influx. They've got a good facility. They run it well. And we don't see major capital going into it. It certainly doesn't require it.

componenttext: I just have one question, which is related to the one that my colleges asked, related acquisition to heavy plates from Joy Global. How does that fit into your portfolio? If you can actually give us a recap of the heat-treating capacity that you have within your [indiscernible] and then what this acquisition may mean in the mid-long term? Because clearly in the U.S. the plate market is the one that's suffering the most both on the capacity and the weakness within the line segment? And his perspective, do you see any kind of potential consolidation among the plates division of your competitors?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we can't comment on what our competitors are going to do. But I'd be happy to comment on your question about how does that fit in with our organization. Well, we talked a little bit about it in terms of just -- in tougher markets and more challengin
componenttext: Well, we can't comment on what our competitors are going to do. But I'd be happy to comment on your question about how does that fit in with our organization. Well, we talked a little bit about it in terms of just -- in tougher markets and more challenging markets, what you want to have is additional product that fits into niche markets. And that's exactly what we're buying here or we have bought here. As I mentioned, several of the applications -- these are really high-quality, specialized applications. We're talking about brackets that go on the airplanes for the landing gears. That's kind of important. And I want to just add a little bit more to what Chad said, just -- look, we can have tremendous commercial leverage here. We sell nationwide. We've got a great commercial team out there selling plates. It wasn't a focus of Joy Global's, so they didn't have the same focus on selling it outside their internal needs. And we do. So we're going to be taking the commercial leverage to the whole another level. And just one final point that I would make, and that's -- listen, it might be weak right now. And while it's not that weak, okay? But we do all the -- the investments that we make for the long-term profitable growth of our company. And we wanted to be sustainable. And we believe that the best way to do that as of today to grow our diversity, continue to grow our market leadership position in the markets in which we participate. And this goes perfectly.

componenttext: A couple of DRI-related questions, as usual. First, if you take a step back and look at the Louisiana DRI project from a big-picture perspective, how does your outlook change over the last year regarding what benefits it might ultimately provide an sort of a midcycle environment? It seems like we've come along way from it was nearly idled after some maintenance last year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start. And Chad, you can jump in here. Clearly, we started our [indiscernible] we do it with many new facilities, there's a learning curve. Tends to be some challenges in equipment. There were in this case. Actually, it had nothing to do with t
componenttext: Well, I'll start. And Chad, you can jump in here. Clearly, we started our [indiscernible] we do it with many new facilities, there's a learning curve. Tends to be some challenges in equipment. There were in this case. Actually, it had nothing to do with the technology. We still have a great deal of confidence in the technology. This was an auxiliary piece of equipment that gave us the issues, a gas heater. So we got -- we worked our way through the equipment issues. And now I would say that it's fitting into our strategy exactly the way that we had anticipated fitting into it. It increases the flexibility of our raw material strategy. Remember that -- and I know you all probably know this, but remember that when you look at iron units, it represents about 60% of our total cost of production. That's a huge portion of our total cost of production. So the more flexible we are, the bigger the basket of choices we have to use -- when we select the lowest-cost mix to put into our furnaces, gives us a tremendous cost advantage, even to our competition. And we still feel very strongly this was a great long-term investment. I'll remind everyone once again that we did build Louisiana with the infrastructure and the support of second facility. And I'm convinced that, long term, okay, as we continue to see prime scrap become more difficult to obtain and degrade in terms of the quality of the prime scrap that's available for our furnaces, and as we continue to move further and further up into the higher-quality products, where we need more and more virgin or very pure iron units, I'll tell you what, we're going to very glad that we have this one. Probably going to be looking to add some more.
