headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]Certain statements made during this conference will be forward-looking statements that invo
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]
Certain statements made during this conference will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future effects -- events will not affect their accuracy. More information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Qs, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's website. The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them, either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Ferriola, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. We appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our other executive vice pr
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. We appreciate your interest in Nucor. 
With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team: Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our other executive vice presidents: Jim Darsey, Ladd Hall, Ray Napolitan, Joe Stratman, Dave Sumoski, and Chad Utermark.
The leadership team in Charlotte would like to thank everyone on our Nucor-Paris deal, David J. Joseph, Duferdofin, NuMit Steel Technologies and Skyline Steel teams for a job well done in the second quarter. Taking advantage of our unrivaled competitive position and our highly flexible business model, you are positioning Nucor to thrive today, and most importantly, in the years ahead. Thank you. 
CFO, Jim Frias, will now review Nucor's second quarter performance and financial position. Following those comments, I will update you on the execution of our strategy of long-term profitable growth. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John.Second quarter 2016 earnings of $0.73 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.70 per diluted share. This performance represents significant improvement over first quarter 2016 earnings of $0.22 per diluted share and yea
componenttext:
Thanks, John.
Second quarter 2016 earnings of $0.73 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.70 per diluted share. This performance represents significant improvement over first quarter 2016 earnings of $0.22 per diluted share and year-ago second quarter earnings of $0.39 per diluted share.
Second quarter results included a LIFO charge of $19 million, which was in line with our guidance. This compared with the first quarter of 2016 charge of $28 million and a year-ago second quarter credit of $96 million. Our steel mills segment was the primary driver of our second quarter profit improvement with the largest gains at our sheet mills. Quarter-over-quarter profit growth was also achieved at our plate and bar mills. Nucor's Steelmaking Operations benefited from both volume growth and higher metal margins. Second quarter total steel mill shipments increased 5% over the first quarter of 2016. Our overall steel mill metal margin expanded by $16 per ton in the second quarter compared to the first quarter. Our downstream products segment also delivered strong earnings growth in second quarter from the first quarter and 2015 second quarter levels. Nucor's steel products business benefits from our market leadership positions and our diversified product portfolio. The strength of Nucor's downstream products business model allows us to profitably leverage a modest improvement in nonresidential construction markets.
Performance at our raw materials segment also improved in the second quarter compared to the first quarter. David J. Joseph Company scrap brokerage and scrap processing businesses were solidly profitable in the second quarter. The improvements at DJJ's recycling business were threefold. First, scrap pricing improved. Second, utilization and volume flows increased to support our steel mills increased production. Third, our scrap processing team has done excellent work achieving efficiency improvements and cost reductions throughout their operations.
Our direct reduced iron, or DRI, facilities achieved significant quarter-over-quarter improvement in their financial performance. At the same time, our raw materials teams continue to enhance Nucor's overall profitability by working with our steel mills to optimize the cost of their iron units. Maintaining Nucor's position as the low-cost producer across our raw materials, steelmaking and steel products businesses is an unrelenting focus for all of our teams.
Our tax rate can be confusing due to the impacted profits from noncontrolling interests. Excluding profits belonging to our business partners, the effective tax rate was approximately 32.5% for the second quarter of 2016.
Nucor's financial position remains strong. Our gross debt-to-capital ratio was 35% at the close of the second quarter. Cash and short-term investments totaled approximately $2.3 billion, which compares with total debt outstanding of $4.4 billion. Nucor's strong liquidity position also includes our $1.5 billion unsecured revolving credit facility, which remains undrawn. The facility does not mature until 2021.
Nucor is the only North-American-headquartered steel producer to hold an investment-grade credit rating. Our capital allocation priorities are clear. They have been consistently and effectively practiced over Nucor's entire history. Our first priority is to invest for profitable, long-term growth that delivers attractive returns on our invested capital. Our second priority is to provide our shareholders with cash dividends that are consistent with our success in growing Nucor's earnings. Our third priority is to opportunistically repurchase our stock when our cash position is strong and attractively priced growth opportunities are limited.
We expect further strong improvement in earnings in the third quarter of 2016. The steel mills segment will benefit from contract pricing resets in the third quarter at our sheet mills. Contracts currently represent about 60% of Nucor's sheet mill volume. The steel products segment continues to experience positive earnings momentum. Particularly strong profit growth is being realized at the rebar fabrication and metal buildings businesses. All of our steel products teams are doing excellent work in managing the challenge of this year's rising steel price environment. The raw materials segment's performance is expected to achieve profitability in the third quarter of 2016. Our DRI facilities will be profitable, benefiting from improved product pricing, lower iron ore costs and continued gains and yield performance. Our Trinidad and Louisiana plants are now consistently performing at what we believe to be world-class conversion cost levels. Our David J. Joseph Company scrap position should also benefit from the more favorable scrap pricing environment that has been in place since the spring of this year. We are confident that Nucor's significant competitive advantages and highly adaptable business model will allow our team to continue to execute our proven strategies for delivering profitable long-term growth and attractive returns to Nucor's shareholders. 
We appreciate your interest in our company. John?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Nucor's strategy for profitable growth is simple, flexible and focused. It is one that we've implemented for more than 5 decades. Nucor capitalizes on its unrivaled position of strength to gain profitable market share in our core businesses o
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Nucor's strategy for profitable growth is simple, flexible and focused. It is one that we've implemented for more than 5 decades. Nucor capitalizes on its unrivaled position of strength to gain profitable market share in our core businesses of steel and steel products. We are doing this by taking care of our customers. Delivering an unrivaled value proposition for our customers is how we earn attractive returns on our shareholders' valuable capital. Anchoring our strategy are Nucor's 5 drivers to profitable growth. They are: strengthen our position as a low-cost producer; achieve market leadership positions in every product line in our portfolio; continue to move up the value chain by expanding our capabilities to produce higher-quality, higher-margin, more import-resistant products; expand and leverage our downstream channels to the market to increase our steel mills' baseload volume, especially in weak markets; and achieve commercial excellence to complement our traditional operational strength. Our strategy for profitable growth is working. It is paying off today with the potential for much larger returns in the future. 
I will now update you on highlights of our recent progress. Nucor's steel mill volume growth in 2016 highlights our success in gaining profitable market share. For the first 6 months of 2016, our steel mill production increased 13% over the year-ago period. That compared with the U.S. steel industry's decrease of approximately 1% over the same period. This profitable growth did not just happen. It is the result of our highly flexible and low-cost production capabilities, our unrivaled product breadth and diversity, our investments that have allowed us to move up the value chain, our execution of our channel-to-market strategy, and most importantly, the hard work done by my more than 23,000 Nucor teammates. 
The best news is that we are far from finished executing our strategy. There's a lot more to come. We are adding cylinders to Nucor's engine for generating higher highs and higher lows in earnings and cash flow. As always, our objective is delivering attractive returns on our shareholders' valuable capital. 
Demand is growing for our Berkeley County, South Carolina sheet mills new, wide-light products. After shipping approximately 160,000 tons of wide-light products in 2015, Berkeley is on track to ship about 270,000 tons in 2016. That's up from their earlier target of 240,000 tons for this year. This wide-light product capability is allowing us to produce more grades of advanced high-strength steels for the automotive market. We are also using wide-light products to gain share in a number of other targeted markets, ranging from appliance to motor lamination to welding wire. 
Our Nucor-Yamato joint venture is continuing to expand its value-added structural steel product portfolio. Last year, Nucor-Yamato began shipping its wider sheet piling sections. These wider sections are lighter and stronger, covering more area at a lower installed cost. Prior to our entry, this market had been largely served by imports. Nucor-Yamato is marketing these sections through our piling distribution business, Skyline Steel. Nucor-Yamato's NZ sheet piling sections are already enjoying strong marketplace success. During the first half of 2016, shipments on the new wide sheet piles have more than tripled to over 19,000 tons; 2 of the 4 wider sheet piling product groups have now been commercialized. The 2 other groups will enter production by the end of this year. Nucor-Yamato's goal over the next several years is to grow our wider sheet piling annual volume to 100,000 tons. Nucor-Yamato is nearing completion of another growth initiative, expanding its value-added structural steel product offerings. A $75 million project, adding Quench and Self-Tempering Technology, will position Nucor-Yamato, as the sole North American producer of high-strength, low-alloy beams. Initial trial production is scheduled to start in September. Trials across the entire range of high-strength, low-alloy beams are expected to be completed by the end of next year's first quarter. These beams allow the use of lighter foot weights, which reduces the weight and cost for the builder. That enhances the competitiveness of steel versus concrete and wood. Nucor-Yamato's target over the next several years is to grow its high-strength, low-alloy beam annual volume to 50,000 tons. 
During the second quarter, our Memphis SBQ bar mill completed installation of its heat-treating equipment and began running trials on new value-added products. This expands our capabilities to include Quench and Tempering as well as annealing of bars from 2.5 inches to 12 inches in diameter. I would like to thank our SBQ bar mill and downstream cold-finished bar teams for their excellent work maintaining profitability in adverse market conditions while also building for future growth with their numerous initiatives moving us up the value chain. 
During the second quarter, our Vulcraft/Verco joist and decking business announced plans to expand its geographical reach into Canada. Vulcraft Canada, our first Vulcraft facility in Canada, will be located near Hamilton, Ontario. It will manufacture steel joists, joist girders and decking. We expect to start producing deck by the end of this year with joist production starting in the first quarter of next year. 
Effective implementation of Nucor's vertical integration and channel-to-market strategy is a key competitive strength and an attractive growth platform for our company. In June, Nucor formed a 50-50 joint venture with JFE Steel of Japan to build and operate a facility to produce galvanized sheet steel for the growing Mexican automotive market. The plant will be strategically located in Central Mexico. It's expected to have a cost of about $270 million. Operations are expected to begin in the second half of 2019. Annual capacity will be approximately 400,000 tons of galvanized sheet steel. It's important to note that Nucor and JFE will each supply an equal amount of substrate to be processed at the facility. We are excited to begin what we expect to be a long-term partnership with JFE Steel, a premier supplier of high-quality automotive steels. 
Yesterday, we announced an agreement to acquire Joy Global's steel plate mill in Longview, Texas, for approximately $29 million. Annual capacity of that facility is about 180,000 tons. The mill produces specialty plate products ranging from 1 to 12 inches thick and up to 138 inches wide. Complementing our existing plate mills' product capability, reaching up to 3 inches thick and 120 inches wide, the Texas mill will enable Nucor to capture a growing share of niche value-added plate markets. We are confident our plate commercial team will be able to leverage this expanded product portfolio to grow our overall plate business. All of these investment projects have the same very simple objective: creating attractive long-term value for our customers, our teammates and our shareholders. 
That discipline drives every capital allocation decision we make at Nucor. Our disciplined approach to being effective stewards of our shareholders' capital also requires that our team tackles significant challenges to our business. To that end, Nucor continues to be proactive and aggressive in pursuing trade cases when and where it is appropriate. When foreign producers and governments break mutually agreed-upon laws governing trade, there must be meaningful consequences. Utilizing trade remedies is not protectionism. Trade enforcement is absolutely critical to drive the change towards a market-based system. A market-based system is one where efficiency and innovation determine which producers win and which producers lose. We are encouraged by recent actions taken by the U.S. government that pave the way for the imposition of much-needed antidumping and countervailing revenues in some products against some countries breaking U.S. and international trade laws. But there remains much more work to be done. As always, Nucor is up to the challenge and will continue fighting hard for free and fair trade. 
I would like to close my remarks by expressing my thanks to our teams at our DRI plants in Trinidad and Louisiana for what they have achieved for Nucor. Your facilities today produce the highest-quality and lowest-cost DRI in the world. Your hard work and perseverance are absolutely critical to our company's success in continuing to move up the value chain. Thank you. And please keep it going.
We would now be happy to answer your questions.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Matthew Korn with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Matthew Korn with Barclays.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're all watching the import numbers carefully. I'm wondering, do your customers show any indication to you, an expectation that they think availability of imported steel is going to meaningfully increase over the rest of the year?
componenttext: So we're all watching the import numbers carefully. I'm wondering, do your customers show any indication to you, an expectation that they think availability of imported steel is going to meaningfully increase over the rest of the year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, the feedback that we get from our customers is that it's frankly the opposite. What our customers are telling us that when they look at the final landed price of the import offers, the difference is great enough to justify the risk. The other po
componenttext: Actually, the feedback that we get from our customers is that it's frankly the opposite. What our customers are telling us that when they look at the final landed price of the import offers, the difference is great enough to justify the risk. The other point that I would make is when you look at where we are in this -- where we are this year, customers buying imports today, placing the orders today, can't really expect the deliveries until sometime in mid -- somewhere -- either early fourth quarter or mid-fourth quarter. And at that point, they're starting to think about their year-end inventories. So I think there's a bit of a hesitation to do too much on the -- ordering on the import side as a result of their concerns over their year-end inventories. I'd also point out a little bit about the -- there's some availability issues and the buyings were less available that are out there today, a lot is the result of the trade cases, the successful prosecution of the trade cases that we've had, particularly in sheet and in some of our other products. And also a concern that our customers have over the other trade cases that are currently in process. So based on all of that information and from the feedback we're getting from our customers, we don't see that as a major concern at this time.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. It's very helpful. Let me follow up this way, if I could. On scrap, how have the flows to the shredders looked so far this summer? So when you look at the moving pieces, the export demand, or lack thereof, competition from cheap Chinese semis, the
componenttext: Got it. It's very helpful. Let me follow up this way, if I could. On scrap, how have the flows to the shredders looked so far this summer? So when you look at the moving pieces, the export demand, or lack thereof, competition from cheap Chinese semis, the high utilization rates from you and the other AF produces, do you see much upside risk to scrap prices over the rest of the year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew, this is Joe Stratman. Let me take a shot at that. The flows have improved through the course of the year, as you might imagine. The increased demand from steel mills across the country raised prices. And with the price increases, flow followed in
componenttext: Matthew, this is Joe Stratman. Let me take a shot at that. The flows have improved through the course of the year, as you might imagine. The increased demand from steel mills across the country raised prices. And with the price increases, flow followed into the scrap yards, which is the normal trend. At this point, with the currency exchange, the strength of the U.S. dollar, the weakness in Europe, in other words, there's a lot of scrap available in Europe. And the Chinese billets moving around the world, the trade flows there, I don't see a lot of upside pressure on scrap. But similarly, the demand, the robust demand for domestic steel mills, I think, also keeps the demand side level. And that we've reached a pretty good point of supply and demand where we would view a lot of stability in the last half of the year on scrap pricing.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Joe, what I might add to that one, when you think about our DRI facilities and the leveling effect that has to our company, and frankly, for the industry, as well as some of the trade line imports that we've been bringing into the country also feelin
componenttext: And, Joe, what I might add to that one, when you think about our DRI facilities and the leveling effect that has to our company, and frankly, for the industry, as well as some of the trade line imports that we've been bringing into the country also feeling [ph] a stabilizing factor.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, John. As I mentioned, the strength of the dollar and the supply available scrap in Europe, but also as John mentioned, pig iron from both Brazil and from Eastern Europe and Russia, the supply is pretty stable right now. And also as John answer
componenttext: Absolutely, John. As I mentioned, the strength of the dollar and the supply available scrap in Europe, but also as John mentioned, pig iron from both Brazil and from Eastern Europe and Russia, the supply is pretty stable right now. And also as John answered in the first part of your question, we think the demand outlook is also good and not negative in any way. So with supply/demand on the scrap side should keep stability there for quite a while, we think.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on trade. You've seen some success on the sheet side. And I was wondering, what is the timing if you wanted to do more incremental work on trade on the sheet and products? So one thing that kind of comes to mind is -- we saw results from
componenttext: First question is on trade. You've seen some success on the sheet side. And I was wondering, what is the timing if you wanted to do more incremental work on trade on the sheet and products? So one thing that kind of comes to mind is -- we saw results from coated, some of the results from cold-rolled and some of the countries are getting similar duties, not many, but Taiwan, for example, included. And I think we'll probably see some cold-rolled results pretty soon. Maybe there'll be another hole or 2 there. For these types of countries, already hearing that maybe some of the Taiwan offers are back in the market again, now that we've gone after them and they kind of escaped, at least this initial lineup of cases, how long does the industry have to wait before they can go after them, again, if they do start to tick up in the future? And then kind of the same question on countries that made key products that weren't named in the initial cases because maybe there weren't big suppliers of the U.S. market, but now that some other guys can't sell into the U.S. market, they're stepping up. And hearing just some talk about cold-rolled coming in from Vietnam and maybe a couple of the European countries, the numbers are starting to tick up a little bit. Is there anything preventing the U.S. industry from going after a fresh round of cases on the same product from different countries?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, to answer that question directly, the answer would be no. Certainly, if we've see an uptick, and the uptick comes with product that is priced at dump levels, and we believe that there's a violation of our trade laws, then we certainly would go after
componenttext: Well, to answer that question directly, the answer would be no. Certainly, if we've see an uptick, and the uptick comes with product that is priced at dump levels, and we believe that there's a violation of our trade laws, then we certainly would go after them, okay? No doubt about that. The other point that I would want to make to the question is when you mentioned about other countries stepping into supply such as Vietnam or some new suppliers, bear in mind that they are untested, they are unqualified in many of these applications and they need to go through an extensive qualification period. And you're taking a larger risk when you look at -- and frankly, the pricing that's coming in is higher from those countries. So when you combine the higher price with the increased risk, with the less places where it can be applied because of the qualifications, we don't see it as much of a threat. But however, to your point, if we do see an uptick in it, and we do see it coming in at dump prices or we see it coming in from countries that are receiving large subsidies from the government or in any way violating our trade and international trade laws, then we are certainly free to take action. On your point about moving to the smaller suppliers, bear in mind, there's [indiscernible] to the fact that we were able to be so successful against the big boys, the big suppliers, the ones who bring in large volumes of steel at incredibly dump prices. When you take that out of the equation, we certainly don't have any problem competing with products coming in at fair prices from other countries as long as they adhere to the trade laws.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then maybe just a quick one for Jim. Corporate expense was pretty high this quarter. I know it's very lumpy. Just wondering what might have been driving that. If we should expect that to return to normal by next quarter?
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then maybe just a quick one for Jim. Corporate expense was pretty high this quarter. I know it's very lumpy. Just wondering what might have been driving that. If we should expect that to return to normal by next quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the biggest driver in the year-to-date difference is LIFO. LIFO went from $112 million credit to a $46.5 million expense. Thats about $160 million swing of the total difference of the $230 million, roughly. The next biggest driver is probably pro
componenttext: Well, the biggest driver in the year-to-date difference is LIFO. LIFO went from $112 million credit to a $46.5 million expense. Thats about $160 million swing of the total difference of the $230 million, roughly. The next biggest driver is probably profit on intercompany sales. We always have some volume of intercompany inventory at our downstream businesses. And with our steel mills having higher margins, we have to take a charge to write that inventory value down to its cost of production. And so there's a takeaway there from the profit steel mills segment. And then finally, we do have a significant part of our pay across the company, including our profit sharing for the retirement accounts of our workforce. That's driven our profitability and thats probably $25-ish million dollars of the difference is in profit sharing and incentive comp being in [indiscernible] we're making more money. It's a good thing. But more than that, the number is changing, the happier our shareholders are.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Late September. Somewhere around late September. So we're looking really good on the cold-rolled and on the galvanized. On the hot-rolled side, we're seeing a little bit more pressure. But that being said, on the hot-rolled side, when we look at the servi
componenttext: Late September. Somewhere around late September. So we're looking really good on the cold-rolled and on the galvanized. On the hot-rolled side, we're seeing a little bit more pressure. But that being said, on the hot-rolled side, when we look at the service center inventory levels, they're extremely low. And with the reduced imports and some of our competitors shutting down operations, we see reduction in supply. So -- although we've seen a slowdown in the order entry rate for hot-rolled, and it's a little bit more challenged in cold-rolled or gal, we're still pretty comfortable with where we are in the hot-rolled market.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. And then second question, just on sort of the M&A pipeline. It seems like there's definitely a hunt on for downstream acquisitions in the industry. And I think one school of thought has been potentially trying to acquire pipe and tube
componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then second question, just on sort of the M&A pipeline. It seems like there's definitely a hunt on for downstream acquisitions in the industry. And I think one school of thought has been potentially trying to acquire pipe and tube assets to leverage the hot band capacity that people have. Is that something that you guys would entertain? And can you just kind of talk to how robust your pipeline is right now for acquisitions?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we mentioned several times that part of our growth strategy is to enhance our channels to the market. And we've had a very successful track record of utilizing our downstream operations not only to get to the final customer as a channel to the marke
componenttext: Well, we mentioned several times that part of our growth strategy is to enhance our channels to the market. And we've had a very successful track record of utilizing our downstream operations not only to get to the final customer as a channel to the market, but also as very, very strong profit generators in their own like. So we're always open to that. I would and -- when were open to many opportunities. We are always out there looking for where we can invest our cash for -- in long-term profitable growth. So I'm not including anything. I'm not excluding anything. And I'm not going to comment anything in particular. But one area that we are focused on, and you'll hear more from us is how we continue to increase on our hot-rolled, since you mentioned specifically what we would do with our hot-rolled. We continue to invest in bringing our hot-rolled to a higher-quality level. Some of the fair work that we're doing in galvanize today is investing to take it out of simply the pricing to the market and get it into high-quality downstream businesses. So general answer, we're interested in everything. We look hard at everything. You've heard us say that we have a very focused but flexible investment strategy, growth strategy. And well look at whatever comes along. We don't have any strong preferences to any particular downstream business.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you just remind us what your hot-rolled mix is relative to the value at sheet in the sheet business?
componenttext: And can you just remind us what your hot-rolled mix is relative to the value at sheet in the sheet business?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's about -- hot-rolled is about 60% -- 60% to 65% of our total sheet business.
componenttext: It's about -- hot-rolled is about 60% -- 60% to 65% of our total sheet business.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Timna Tanners with Bank of America and Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from Timna Tanners with Bank of America and Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you a little bit more about your product mix, if you could drill down just looking at your data here. We're kind of surprised to see the structural number decline. And even though the sheet number bounced a lot, I think it was discussed at
componenttext: I wanted to ask you a little bit more about your product mix, if you could drill down just looking at your data here. We're kind of surprised to see the structural number decline. And even though the sheet number bounced a lot, I think it was discussed at 5 50 average is much lower than where the stock market's been, even just for HRC. And I know there's a lag. But are we missing something? Or is there another reason why the average sheet price is so much lower? Even looking at CRE numbers, I can't quite reconcile them. So I'm just wondering if you could give us a little more color.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you hit the nail on the head when you talk about our contract pricing. We have a very large percentage of our sheet business under contract. And it does lag. And most people tend to just think about it as a single-month lag. But when you add into th
componenttext: Well, you hit the nail on the head when you talk about our contract pricing. We have a very large percentage of our sheet business under contract. And it does lag. And most people tend to just think about it as a single-month lag. But when you add into the lead times that are involved, you have to really extend that out a little bit. So when it comes to your question about pricing on sheet, I would say that without a doubt, the issue there is a large percentage of contract pricing. And we expect to have -- to pick that up in the third quarter. So we're looking forward to that happening. On the question about structural, we had a nice jump in our structural percentage from quarter-over-quarter last quarter. So it's not unusual for us to see a smaller jump quarter-over-quarter in second quarter over first quarter.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Timna, this is Chad. Just to comment. Overall demand for structural product year-over-year is up about 3% or 4%. Our Nucor shipments of structural steel is up about 15%. So while quarter-over-quarter we dropped just a tad, a significant part of that was t
componenttext: Timna, this is Chad. Just to comment. Overall demand for structural product year-over-year is up about 3% or 4%. Our Nucor shipments of structural steel is up about 15%. So while quarter-over-quarter we dropped just a tad, a significant part of that was the major outages that we had at Nucor-Yamato.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to be clear, I was asking about prices. Are you talking -- whether there may be a mix shift or something that caused that decline? Is that what you're saying?
componenttext: So just to be clear, I was asking about prices. Are you talking -- whether there may be a mix shift or something that caused that decline? Is that what you're saying?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, mix can play a huge role on our pricing, on our structural side. Yes.
componenttext: Obviously, mix can play a huge role on our pricing, on our structural side. Yes.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay. In the last quarter, I asked about -- a question I'm going to ask the same one again, make it nice and easy for you. So you were running at 2.4 million tons of sheet in the first quarter and you're at 2.5 million. So you did ramp up as we d
componenttext: Got you. Okay. In the last quarter, I asked about -- a question I'm going to ask the same one again, make it nice and easy for you. So you were running at 2.4 million tons of sheet in the first quarter and you're at 2.5 million. So you did ramp up as we discussed. But I'm still perplexed as the answer then you said was 11.5 million to 12 million annualized tons is more normal and an annualized base is just still running at 10 million tons. So the question is, do you have spare capacity to run more sheet in light of these tight market conditions?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have limited capacity certainly on cold-rolled and gal. I would say we have some capacity available on hot-rolled as we look out past the next couple of weeks. One of the other things -- Chad mentioned the issue of mix not moving the same thing u
componenttext: Well, we have limited capacity certainly on cold-rolled and gal. I would say we have some capacity available on hot-rolled as we look out past the next couple of weeks. One of the other things -- Chad mentioned the issue of mix not moving the same thing up on the side of hot-rolled. So as we continue to shift our mix higher and higher on the value-added, a lot of that product runs slower on our mills. And we can produce less number of tons. The poster child example of that would be at our Berkeley mill with a wide-light product move -- moving into the advanced high strength steels. To produce a high strength steel product there's a lot -- takes extra time in the LML, [ph] takes extra time in the vacuum tank degasser. And then of course, running at those very wide gauges, it takes extra time to run through the mill. So it's basically a question of mix, more than anything else.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I understand, you're saying on the hot-rolled you may have a little more capacity in general, but you're brimming pretty full out on the more premium sheet grade? Is that fair?
componenttext: So if I understand, you're saying on the hot-rolled you may have a little more capacity in general, but you're brimming pretty full out on the more premium sheet grade? Is that fair?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Exactly.
componenttext: Yes. Exactly.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Jorge Beristain with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jorge Beristain with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jorge Beristain with DB. I guess, most of my questions have been asked, but maybe you could comment a little bit about -- with the Big River plant coming up in the fourth quarter this year or 1Q '17, the current supply tightness that we're seeing in the m
componenttext: Jorge Beristain with DB. I guess, most of my questions have been asked, but maybe you could comment a little bit about -- with the Big River plant coming up in the fourth quarter this year or 1Q '17, the current supply tightness that we're seeing in the market, are you bracing for any kind of impact of new supply coming into the market?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So going back to your question about Big River steel coming online. Certainly, that will add supply. Are we concerned about it? Well, it's a competitor. That's a good thing. We've had new competitors coming online in the past over the last several years.
componenttext: So going back to your question about Big River steel coming online. Certainly, that will add supply. Are we concerned about it? Well, it's a competitor. That's a good thing. We've had new competitors coming online in the past over the last several years. We deal with it. We're not afraid of competition. And I would say to you that, frankly, it's more than just equipment that comes online. You got to have the relationships with the customers. You got teammates who understand how to make the products. You have to -- we have advantages such as our diversity, an advantage that I believe we would have over them or other competitors is our vertical integration and our ability to take advantage of that vertical integration. So we'll -- they'll come online. We'll deal with them. And one of the things that is nice about having extra competition that's coming from the domestic source is, they do play by the same rules as us and they can't cheat. And we like that. So I'll take extra competition from a U.S. supplier than international one any day of the week.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other question I had was just maybe on supplier discipline within the U.S. market. Are you hearing that everybody is adhering to their official list prices? Or could you comment a little bit about -- if there's any kind of breakdown of discipline?
componenttext: The other question I had was just maybe on supplier discipline within the U.S. market. Are you hearing that everybody is adhering to their official list prices? Or could you comment a little bit about -- if there's any kind of breakdown of discipline?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't comment on what other supplies are doing. And I won't, okay? I can only tell you what we're doing about our -- in our business. So if you have a question that's specific to Nucor, Id be happy to answer it, but I can't comment on what others are
componenttext: I can't comment on what other supplies are doing. And I won't, okay? I can only tell you what we're doing about our -- in our business. So if you have a question that's specific to Nucor, Id be happy to answer it, but I can't comment on what others are doing.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Seth Rosenfeld with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Seth Rosenfeld with Jefferies.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit more about the output for your DRI facilities? And quite a little bit more to what extent the improving outlook for Q3 earnings is driven by your input cost and sales price expectations for the period versus yield improvements
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit more about the output for your DRI facilities? And quite a little bit more to what extent the improving outlook for Q3 earnings is driven by your input cost and sales price expectations for the period versus yield improvements as Louisiana continues to ramp up? And then looking further out, if you can just comment on what the cost sensitivity would be since the -- rising gas prices looking forward?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Lyle. I'll take a shot at that. Theres no question the biggest driver of our improvement in our DRI plants are our costs and our yield improvements. They've done a superb job down there. Figuring out how to take a huge amount of yield loss
componenttext: Yes, this is Lyle. I'll take a shot at that. Theres no question the biggest driver of our improvement in our DRI plants are our costs and our yield improvements. They've done a superb job down there. Figuring out how to take a huge amount of yield loss out of that product. In fact, they continue to keep a very, very high level of quality. Steel Mills are usually learning how to use their materials better and better. And in fact, more of our steel [indiscernible] they would use it far above HBI and getting very close the same quality of what the pig really is. So we're really excited about what that is. And secondly, we don't really control the price, it depends on ore prices, pig prices and scrap prices. So they have to be market competitive to do that. And to tell that we're going to be profitable in third quarter at our DRI plants and finish their market, really speaks highly what those 2 plants have done.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would add just one point to that because you asked specifically about gas pricing and you remember that with our -- deal up in Canada, and we have some control over there. We have some ability to mitigate the impact of gas price increasing with our
componenttext: And I would add just one point to that because you asked specifically about gas pricing and you remember that with our -- deal up in Canada, and we have some control over there. We have some ability to mitigate the impact of gas price increasing with our own supply from Canada.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not to mention we have a long-term gas contract in Trinidad.
componenttext: Not to mention we have a long-term gas contract in Trinidad.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And its good point, also, yes. Thank you.
componenttext: And its good point, also, yes. Thank you.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Garrett Nelson with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Have your CapEx or D&A expectations changed at all since last call? And could you also remind us what Nucor's company-wide maintenance CapEx is?
componenttext: Have your CapEx or D&A expectations changed at all since last call? And could you also remind us what Nucor's company-wide maintenance CapEx is?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we say the maintenance CapEx is in the neighborhood of $350 million. And our outlook for the year remains the same. It's roughly $500 million for the year.
componenttext: Yes, we say the maintenance CapEx is in the neighborhood of $350 million. And our outlook for the year remains the same. It's roughly $500 million for the year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the steel mills utilization rate, the 83% that you reported for Q2, are you still assuming the same nameplate capacity as you were before? Has that number changed a little bit?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the steel mills utilization rate, the 83% that you reported for Q2, are you still assuming the same nameplate capacity as you were before? Has that number changed a little bit?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent question. And again, to get into the nuts and bolts. We're not going to spend a lot of time getting into the details, but the direct answer to your question is yes. We do keep that number constant. And that's something that we're evaluating righ
componenttext: Excellent question. And again, to get into the nuts and bolts. We're not going to spend a lot of time getting into the details, but the direct answer to your question is yes. We do keep that number constant. And that's something that we're evaluating right now as we look at how some others report the numbers. And we typically have the same number year after year after year, so that we can compare ourselves quarter over quarter over quarter. Others using the typical mixes or what they anticipate their product mix to be to -- for the quarter to generate a denominator and then, of course, a capacity utilization.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would add, John, that our numbers are not a nameplate number. They're usually higher than the nameplate number because at some point in time in history, you usually go on above the nameplate number. And so we typically report based on the peak we co
componenttext: And I would add, John, that our numbers are not a nameplate number. They're usually higher than the nameplate number because at some point in time in history, you usually go on above the nameplate number. And so we typically report based on the peak we could achieve in ideal circumstance for the perfect mix, not based on what the current market mix might be or other factors like that, that can influence the mix.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's absolutely correct. Frankly, we would be really disappointed if what we've generated is kind of [indiscernible] production was what the nameplate said. Our goal is to exceed that at all times. Having said all of that, I will tell you that the
componenttext: Yes, that's absolutely correct. Frankly, we would be really disappointed if what we've generated is kind of [indiscernible] production was what the nameplate said. Our goal is to exceed that at all times. Having said all of that, I will tell you that the other thing that comes into play here is that, as I mentioned earlier in one or the other questions, our mix is changing dramatically to higher quality, higher profitable products. As a result, they tend to run slower on our mills. So we are taking a look at evaluating just where we are with that during the next quarter and perhaps resetting those numbers at the end of the year. I don't think -- in fact, I'm sure we won't go one where we change it quarter by quarter by quarter. We just don't think that's a fair way to represent our utilization, but we will evaluate where we are today based upon our new product mix that we are running the higher-quality, slower-running products in our mills.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Phil Gibbs with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Phil Gibbs with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

componenttext: John, on the hot-rolled book you mentioned, there's a little bit of pressure there more recently, maybe the lead times have come in. componenttext: Yes, planned [indiscernible] somewhat just Crawfordsville, Indiana plant. And has frankly skipped that with [indiscernible] do a mini 4-day outage this quarter. componenttext: And to answer your question directly, we aren't anticipating changing of -- any of our maintenance shutdowns to deal with the issue. We don't think it's -- we need to do that at this time.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: How long do you think, based on your feel, buyers can hold off in terms of [indiscernible] will stand-off. We're hearing about and seeing in the marketplace?
componenttext: How long do you think, based on your feel, buyers can hold off in terms of [indiscernible] will stand-off. We're hearing about and seeing in the marketplace?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I can't answer that question. That's a question more for our buyers. But what I will point you to is when you take a look at the months-on-hand numbers, they're extremely low. You talked about across all sheet products, months on hand is about 2.0.
componenttext: Well, I can't answer that question. That's a question more for our buyers. But what I will point you to is when you take a look at the months-on-hand numbers, they're extremely low. You talked about across all sheet products, months on hand is about 2.0. That's extremely low. Now we suspect that if you break that down, look at cold-rolled and galvanized, probably a little bit under that, maybe 1.6, 1.7, 1.8. So hot band might be somewhere around 2.2 or something in that name -- in that area. All of that said, that's still an extremely low number. Now certainly, buyers are hesitant to buy right now. There is lot of things going on. But we think that as things settle down, as people start coming back from the vacations and they begin to look at what their plans are for the rest of the year, we expect them to buy -- to get back into the game.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate all that color. And one of your competitors yesterday talked about some [indiscernible] buying in lawn products in the second quarter with maybe a little hangover effect in 3Q. I didn't seem to see that in your numbers. I think the bar and st
componenttext: I appreciate all that color. And one of your competitors yesterday talked about some [indiscernible] buying in lawn products in the second quarter with maybe a little hangover effect in 3Q. I didn't seem to see that in your numbers. I think the bar and structural volumes were fairly consistent quarter-on-quarter. Anything that you could comment on there in terms of your business and that sort of comment?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil, this is Jim Darsey. While there were little orders advanced in the second quarter we see demand in the third quarter for merchants being steady, driven primarily by the continued growth in nonresidential construction and the 2.7 month service center
componenttext: Phil, this is Jim Darsey. While there were little orders advanced in the second quarter we see demand in the third quarter for merchants being steady, driven primarily by the continued growth in nonresidential construction and the 2.7 month service center inventory. So they are buying. And on the rebar side demand, even though we have a lot of imports coming into the country, demand is fairly strong, driven by construction. So we see rebar demand continuing, feel a little price pressure there and merchant barges will continue on pretty steady.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would add to that, Jim, if I could, the [indiscernible] on the rebar, we do see a little bit of challenge there, as you mentioned, because of the imports. Remember that we have the downstream business that consumes about 1.4 million tons of our reba
componenttext: And I would add to that, Jim, if I could, the [indiscernible] on the rebar, we do see a little bit of challenge there, as you mentioned, because of the imports. Remember that we have the downstream business that consumes about 1.4 million tons of our rebar, which puts us in a really good position in terms of our rebar generation and sales.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good point, John. Thank you.
componenttext: Yes. Good point, John. Thank you.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any comments you can make, Jim or John, on the structural business?
componenttext: Any comments you can make, Jim or John, on the structural business?

componenttext: Phil, this is Chad. Like Jim said, on the structural side of the business, as we head into third quarter, demand is relatively flat. And we go in with a decent backlog. So I would say it's pretty much steady as we look forward.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are excited to begin -- introduce our new products, our new piling sections will be coming out in the second half with 2 remaining piling sections will be coming out during the second half of the year. And we're really excited to be able to be introduc
componenttext: We are excited to begin -- introduce our new products, our new piling sections will be coming out in the second half with 2 remaining piling sections will be coming out during the second half of the year. And we're really excited to be able to be introducing our QSB product in the near future. That's going to be a big plus to our structural mills.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Aldo Mazzaferro with Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Aldo Mazzaferro with Macquarie.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a couple of questions. One on the scrap business and then on a couple of your growth initiatives. On the scrap side, since you have much more of a brokerage distribution setup rather than shredding domestically and things like that, I'm wo
componenttext: I wanted to ask a couple of questions. One on the scrap business and then on a couple of your growth initiatives. On the scrap side, since you have much more of a brokerage distribution setup rather than shredding domestically and things like that, I'm wondering, does that give you an advantage to buy foreign scrap that other domestic scrap players might not be able to take advantage of? And [indiscernible]

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Aldo, this is Joe Stratman. We certainly see it as an advantage. We do have an international reach through our brokerage team, our DJJ brokerage team. We can bring scrap in from virtually all over the world. And we can bring scrap substitutes in from virt
componenttext: Aldo, this is Joe Stratman. We certainly see it as an advantage. We do have an international reach through our brokerage team, our DJJ brokerage team. We can bring scrap in from virtually all over the world. And we can bring scrap substitutes in from virtually all over the world. The advantage clearly is it provides us a great deal of flexibility to use all the resources across the globe to get the most cost-effective source of raw material. So at times, it will be domestic scrap. At times, it will be international scrap substitute. So we certainly believe it's an advantage. And we certainly use it to our best advantage.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not just on [indiscernible] that's why we're also doing it on [indiscernible]
componenttext: Not just on [indiscernible] that's why we're also doing it on [indiscernible]

componenttextpreview: Yes, we do the same thing through -- again, through the DJJ team in cooperation with our steel mills. We do that also on ferro-alloys.
componenttext: Yes, we do the same thing through -- again, through the DJJ team in cooperation with our steel mills. We do that also on ferro-alloys.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's what we'll be looking for. And bear in mind that in addition to processing and brokerage, DJ Joseph also has other businesses that serve us well. Their railcar business, a big plus for us. They give some advantages. And I've always said this and I
componenttext: That's what we'll be looking for. And bear in mind that in addition to processing and brokerage, DJ Joseph also has other businesses that serve us well. Their railcar business, a big plus for us. They give some advantages. And I've always said this and I still believe. DJ Joseph is not just a scrap company and a brokerage company and a rail company. More important than anything for us, it's an information company. And they do a great job of tracking the price of iron units and alloys worldwide and helping us understand what's going on in other countries in terms of consumption of the product by the amount of buying units that are being consumed, alloys that are being consumed. So it's a great information company that serves us extremely well.

componenttext: Yes, certainly, I can say why it's Central America -- Central Mexico, excuse me. That's because that's where the customers are. We put the plant where the customers are. When you look at where are the -- all of the automotive companies are locating their production facilities. It's right in that same area around Len and surrounding communities. So we're placing this. We haven't decided exactly which town to put it in. But were placing it in a location that's frankly surrounded by new automotive company, new automotive production that's going in around that. Because in terms of the substrate, in terms of the substrate, about 50% of the substrate or 200,000 tons will be coming from Nucor and 200,000 tons will be coming from JFE.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me say, I don't refer to it is a little plate company in Texas. I'm going to say it's a great, great plate company in Texas. And I'm very glad that you asked this question because I wanted to take just a minute and to welcome all of our new team
componenttext: Well, let me say, I don't refer to it is a little plate company in Texas. I'm going to say it's a great, great plate company in Texas. And I'm very glad that you asked this question because I wanted to take just a minute and to welcome all of our new teammates from Longview, Texas, into the Nucor family. So any of you who are listening to this call today, we're excited to have you on board. Welcome. I want to tell you, I was at that facility yesterday to -- frankly to welcome everyone into the company and drove around and walked around that facility. That's a great -- it's a great facility. We've had a very good price, okay? A very fair price. And if you work it out, it comes out to about $161 a ton for a plate mill. And that's pretty good price. Why are we doing it? Well, there's a lot of good reasons. Number one, and Chad, you can jump if I miss any here. But number one, just from a sizing perspective, it really feels a void that we've had in our portfolio. We want to be able to offer our customers a full range of plate products. And currently today, we go up to -- I think I'm thinking going to get this right, correct me if I'm not, 3 inches in thickness and 128 inches in width. And with the facility in Longview, we call it Nucor Longview, okay? We'll be able to go up to 12 inches and, I believe, it's 138 inches in width. And beyond that, because they utilize what's known as the bottom forward ingot process, okay, you get extremely clean steels that allow us to sell into many, many high-quality, higher-margin applications. Military applications, naval applications, airplanes, I think, they make great brackets for our -- for some of the airplane applications. [indiscernible] market they go into well, heavy equipment market they go into. And in addition to production, they have an incredible heat-treating and annealing operation. If I have it correct, I think it's 18 heat-treating facilities, they call them bottle -- up-bottom -- excuse me, bottom furnaces for heat treating. And I'm going to tell you what, I spent -- I've visited a couple of weeks ago. And I was there again yesterday. Best of all, I mentioned all the great equipment they have but more importantly than any of that, they've got a great workforce, their culture is fantastic. It's a great cultural fit with Nucor. And if you can't tell by the tone of my voice, I'll tell you, I'm really excited to have them join the Nucor team.

componenttext: Yes. This is Chad Utermark. Just to add on to what John said at the specialty products at this mill is capable of making into these valuable niche markets, more value-added markets that we want to penetrate. I'd be remiss if I didn't mention that our current North American commercial footprint that we already have in place and this great relationship we have with plate customers all across United States, we're going to be able to bring this product to market very quickly. And like John said, I'm excited to have this asset. But more importantly, the team that's down there, what a great group of men and women, and we're excited about moving forward.

They run it well. And we don't see major capital going into it. It certainly doesn't require it.

componenttext: I just have one question, which is related to the one that my colleagues have asked, related to the acquisition of the heavy plates from Joy Global. How does it fit into your portfolio? If you can actually give us a recap of the heat-treating capacity that you have within your mills, and what this acquisition may mean in the mid-long term? Because clearly in the U.S. the plate market is the one that's suffering the most, both on the capacity and weakness within the line segment? componenttext: Well, we can't comment on what our competitors are going to do. But I'd be happy to comment on your question about how does that fit in with our organization. Well, we talked a little bit about it in terms of just -- in tougher markets and more challenging markets, what you want to have is additional products that fit into niche markets. And that's exactly what we're buying here or we have bought here. As I mentioned, several of the applications -- these are really high-quality, specialized applications. We're talking about brackets that go on the airplanes for the landing gears. That's kind of important. And I want to just add a little bit more to what Chad said, also that -- look, we're going to have tremendous commercial leverage here. We sell nationwide. We've got a great commercial team out there selling plates. It wasn't a focus of Joy Global's, so they didn't have the same focus on selling it outside their internal needs. And we do. So we're going to be taking the commercial levels to the whole another level. And just one final point that I would make, and that's -- listen, it might be weak right now. And while frankly it's not that weak, okay? But we do all those -- the investments that we make are for the long-term profitable growth of our company. And we want it to be sustainable. And we believe that the best way to do that is continue to grow our diversity, continue to grow our market leadership position in the markets in which we participate. And this goes perfectly.

componenttext: A couple of DRI-related questions, as usual. First, if you were to take a step back and look at the Louisiana DRI project from a big-picture perspective, how has your outlook changed over the last year regarding what benefits it might ultimately provide and sort of a mid-cycle environment? It seems like we've come a long way from when it was nearly idled after some maintenance last year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start. And Ladd, you can jump in here. Clearly, when we started off as we do it with many new facilities, there's a learning curve. There tends to be some challenges on equipment. There were in this case. Actually, it had nothing to do with the
componenttext: Well, I'll start. And Ladd, you can jump in here. Clearly, when we started off as we do it with many new facilities, there's a learning curve. There tends to be some challenges on equipment. There were in this case. Actually, it had nothing to do with the technology. We still have a great deal of confidence in the technology. This was an auxiliary piece of equipment that gave us the issues, a gas heater. So we got -- we worked our way through the equipment issues. And now I would say that it's fitting into our strategy exactly the way that we had anticipated fitting into it. It increases the flexibility of our raw material strategy. Remember that -- and I know you all probably know this, but remember that when you look at iron units, it represents about 60% of our total cost of production. That's a huge portion of our total cost of production. So the more flexible we are, the bigger the basket of choices we have to use -- when we select the lowest-cost mix to put into our furnaces, gives us a tremendous cost advantage to our competition. And we still feel very strong this was a great long-term investment. I'll remind everyone once again that we did build Louisiana with the infrastructure and the support of second facility. And I'm convinced that, long term, okay, as we continue to see prime scrap become more difficult to obtain and to grade in terms of the quality of the prime scrap that's available for our furnaces, and as we continue to move further and further up into the higher-quality products, where we need more and more virgin or very pure iron units, I'll tell you what, we're going to very glad that we have this. And we're probably going to be looking to add some more.
