headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. And then just with respect to trade and the Vietnam petition, it seems like there's a prevalent view that processing or cold-rolling material in Vietnam doesn't fundamentally change the nature -- or does fundamentally change what t
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And then just with respect to trade and the Vietnam petition, it seems like there's a prevalent view that processing or cold-rolling material in Vietnam doesn't fundamentally change the nature -- or does fundamentally change what the product is. Can you just kind of comment on the nuance of that and how you think the Department of Commerce is going to treat that issue specifically?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not going to go into too much detail as this is an ongoing investigation and there has not been a final determination on this. We feel strongly, very strongly, that our position is a strong one. It's clear to us. Our opinion is it's clearly an i
componenttext: Well, I'm not going to go into too much detail as this is an ongoing investigation and there has not been a final determination on this. We feel strongly, very strongly, that our position is a strong one. It's clear to us. Our opinion is it's clearly an issue of circumvention. You can look at the percentage of imports of cold-rolled product from China into Vietnam and seen the tremendous jump over the last 6 months. It's clear what's going on. And we think that particularly, when you look at the political environment today, where both sides of the aisle is a recognition of what's going on around the world with illegal trade, I feel and our team feels very confident that we'll be successful in the circumvention case.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Jorge Beristain with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jorge Beristain with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe, John, if you could comment about the current pricing that you're seeing in -- sorry, in the heavy plate market. We just noticed that plate prices have fallen and are basically now below HRC, and you recently announced a price hike. So if you'll jus
componenttext: Maybe, John, if you could comment about the current pricing that you're seeing in -- sorry, in the heavy plate market. We just noticed that plate prices have fallen and are basically now below HRC, and you recently announced a price hike. So if you'll just kind of talk about what you're seeing in that market? That's my first question.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me -- I'll start off then I'll hand it over to Chad, our Executive Vice President in charge of our plate business. But just as a general comment, obviously we're not going to speak about any pricing specific, but the plate market has been very c
componenttext: Well, let me -- I'll start off then I'll hand it over to Chad, our Executive Vice President in charge of our plate business. But just as a general comment, obviously we're not going to speak about any pricing specific, but the plate market has been very challenging. It's been a tough year on plate. It doesn't look like it's getting much better towards the end of the year. We can go market by market, but there's no strong market right now that we would point to say that we're going to see a big pop in pricing. I would make one comment and then, Chad, you can build on this. When you look at the pricing levels in plate today, personally I feel they're just not sustainable over the long term. But Chad, would you like to add anything to that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, John. I agree, the plate market is very challenged currently. Your assessment of where plate prices are compared to hot roll is true that being below hot-rolled prices, which they are now according to CRU, is something that we have rarely see
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, John. I agree, the plate market is very challenged currently. Your assessment of where plate prices are compared to hot roll is true that being below hot-rolled prices, which they are now according to CRU, is something that we have rarely seen over the history of pricing. So I do not believe that's sustainable long term. There is some fundamental demand challenges out there in the plate market right now. And we did announce recently a plate price increase. That was late last week, and we are monitoring that situation at this time.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just might mention too, Chad, that we've been -- have a successful plate trade case against a violator who was dumping a significant amount of plate into the country, and that was China. And we had a very positive outcome on that case.
componenttext: I just might mention too, Chad, that we've been -- have a successful plate trade case against a violator who was dumping a significant amount of plate into the country, and that was China. And we had a very positive outcome on that case.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And there's a very important date coming up in November where we'll get the AD rulings from Commerce on the remaining 8 countries. So those are some of the things that we're monitoring closely in the plate market.
componenttext: Yes. And there's a very important date coming up in November where we'll get the AD rulings from Commerce on the remaining 8 countries. So those are some of the things that we're monitoring closely in the plate market.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And sorry, I had a second question if possible. Just housekeeping on Independence Tube. Would you be segmenting that under your steel products or your structural steel tube segment or just kind of -- sorry, your steel mills segment? Just trying to
componenttext: Great. And sorry, I had a second question if possible. Just housekeeping on Independence Tube. Would you be segmenting that under your steel products or your structural steel tube segment or just kind of -- sorry, your steel mills segment? Just trying to understand sort of how you view that operation in terms of value add.

componenttext: Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Right now, we're probably going to put it in steel products. We haven't made a final determination, but we're thinking it belongs to steel products.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Timna Tanners with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to Timna Tanners with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: In light of the fact that met coal is all of a sudden back to the reason that you, I think, started to invest in DRI, I wanted to get a sense of, if we were to believe that scrap moves with met, are we looking at it again returning to that advantage that
componenttext: In light of the fact that met coal is all of a sudden back to the reason that you, I think, started to invest in DRI, I wanted to get a sense of, if we were to believe that scrap moves with met, are we looking at it again returning to that advantage that you were hoping for in DRI? And how are you thinking about what hedge that might offer you in a strong met coal environment into 2017?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, there are many -- there are several things that scrap tends to be -- scrap pricing tends to be linked to. Certainly, one of the most important is volume. Now as the build business picks up and people have a greater demand for scrap, the pri
componenttext: Well, clearly, there are many -- there are several things that scrap tends to be -- scrap pricing tends to be linked to. Certainly, one of the most important is volume. Now as the build business picks up and people have a greater demand for scrap, the price of scrap goes up. And there's also a linkage, as you mentioned, to coking coal, and we expect to see some small increase as a result of that. But as we see scrap right now, scrap is a pretty low number. We think it's probably at the bottom. We -- as we look out for the rest of the year, we might see a small incremental increase but nothing substantial. Joe, anything you want to add to that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you really covered it, John. The -- as we head into the winter, there's always going to be a seasonality issue or potential on scrap flow. Northern scrap yards need to close down or slow down, et cetera. But any strength that gives us is proba
componenttext: No, I think you really covered it, John. The -- as we head into the winter, there's always going to be a seasonality issue or potential on scrap flow. Northern scrap yards need to close down or slow down, et cetera. But any strength that gives us is probably just seasonal. And ultimately, it'll follow the demand in the steel mills.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now I will take it away from scrap for a minute and say that as you look at what's going to happen, as these companies are going into next year's contract for buying coking coal, that we believe that there will be an increase based upon the current spot p
componenttext: Now I will take it away from scrap for a minute and say that as you look at what's going to happen, as these companies are going into next year's contract for buying coking coal, that we believe that there will be an increase based upon the current spot price. And obviously, on final product, we see that that's going to put us in a more competitive position than we were when coking coal was at half the price it is today.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And DRI versus pig iron? Same story, maybe a little more explicit connection to the met coal price?
componenttext: Right. And DRI versus pig iron? Same story, maybe a little more explicit connection to the met coal price?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes
componenttext: Yes

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Timna. This is Joe Stratman. Clearly, that's true. I mean, obviously, one of the major cost components of either pig iron or DRI is what form of reductant do you use and what reductant that -- what cost that reductant is at. So if you compare the cos
componenttext: Yes, Timna. This is Joe Stratman. Clearly, that's true. I mean, obviously, one of the major cost components of either pig iron or DRI is what form of reductant do you use and what reductant that -- what cost that reductant is at. So if you compare the cost of coking coal as you reducted in a pig iron environment versus natural gas in a DRI environment, you can clearly see some cost differential depending on where those 2 commodities are moving --

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Timna, if I can just add something quickly. And that is, this is exactly why we moved forward with the DRI strategy. We look at it, as we've talked about many times, this is a hedge. It gives us the flexibility, gives us balance. And as the cost of ra
componenttext: And Timna, if I can just add something quickly. And that is, this is exactly why we moved forward with the DRI strategy. We look at it, as we've talked about many times, this is a hedge. It gives us the flexibility, gives us balance. And as the cost of raw materials change, and the cost of raw materials in steelmaking represent more than 50% of the cost of the product, this gives us a tremendous advantage as things shift. And given our DRI and our D.J. Joseph Company, the ability to buy pig iron or HBI when it makes sense, our DRI facilities, be able to buy scrap internationally, these are the kinds of things when you have these kind of movements, as we've seen today with coking cold, that really point to the value of our long-term raw material strategy.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. That's why I asked about it, because we're back to those met coal prices.
componenttext: Sure. That's why I asked about it, because we're back to those met coal prices.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, big question.
componenttext: Oh, big question.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Part -- yes. Here we are again.
componenttext: Part -- yes. Here we are again.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: They [ph] need to brag on.
componenttext: They [ph] need to brag on.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: There you go. Oh, okay. All right, I'll ask a tougher question now. I'll try. Now I know you talk about -- oh, I guess I'll ask about Big River, I guess, to ask a tougher question. By the end of the year, we're expecting Big River volumes to come on. That
componenttext: There you go. Oh, okay. All right, I'll ask a tougher question now. I'll try. Now I know you talk about -- oh, I guess I'll ask about Big River, I guess, to ask a tougher question. By the end of the year, we're expecting Big River volumes to come on. That is a little bit in your geographic sweet spot. I know that Nucor has been moving away from commodity steels and to more value-add products. But can you give us a little bit more color on how you're thinking about the arrival of Big River values -- volume and what that means for Nucor?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's another competitor, and we've never shied away from competition. As long as it's fair and legal, we love it. And we're confident that we can take it on without having an impact upon our business. Now certainly, it's going to hurt the market. Certainl
componenttext: It's another competitor, and we've never shied away from competition. As long as it's fair and legal, we love it. And we're confident that we can take it on without having an impact upon our business. Now certainly, it's going to hurt the market. Certainly, that's going to have an influence on the market. But given what we've been doing, particularly in the Southeast and in the markets that we have been targeting, as we move up the value chain, certainly it's going to be a while before they can move up into the same areas that -- or products that we're producing, particularly the high-strengths, 95 [ph] strengths and the automotive kind of markets that we're moving into. So you're right, as we move away from more and more -- away from the, well, commodity grades, we'll have less of an impact. I'll also point out to you, Timna, you heard in our script about our Specialty Cold Mill Complex that's going into [indiscernible]. I might point out the difference. I don't know how many miles but not that many miles away from Big River Steel. And we are confident that the unique mill equipment that we're putting in there is going to give us an ability to produce products that we can't produce today, but products that certainly Big River can't produce today. And we think that, that will give us another edge over them as they come up with their more commoditized products.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And if I could slip one last one in on that, well, same day[ph]. I mean, if we expect, let's say, hypothetically auto is flat going forward from here, is there a case to be made that Nucor could continue to increase its share there? And can y
componenttext: Okay, great. And if I could slip one last one in on that, well, same day[ph]. I mean, if we expect, let's say, hypothetically auto is flat going forward from here, is there a case to be made that Nucor could continue to increase its share there? And can you quantify that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, we're very confident. We -- first of all, just to comment on your statement, we agree. We think that going into 2017, autos will be basically flat. We don't see it going up. It might go down a little bit, but we don't see it changing significantly
componenttext: Listen, we're very confident. We -- first of all, just to comment on your statement, we agree. We think that going into 2017, autos will be basically flat. We don't see it going up. It might go down a little bit, but we don't see it changing significantly. And even in that environment, we will continue to grow our market share not only in the types of products that we can produce that go into automotive, but frankly in the number of automotive companies that have an interest in doing business with us. As we've said many times, our target is to reach 2 million tons by 2018. Today, we're somewhere around 1.4 million, 1.45 million, in that range. And the team here will tell you that our next target is 3 million tons by 2021. I will tell you that our next target is 3 million tons by 2020. And frankly, the JV that we -- you've heard us talk about in the script, the JV with JFE is going to be a big boost not only in that particular project or on the galvanizing side, but, frankly, the recognition that Nucor has achieved by being picked as a partner with JFE clearly the premier automotive steel producer in the world will put to bed finally this argument about whether or not automotive-grade steels can be made in an electric arc furnace shop, particular one that has Nucor name on the front of the facility.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question for you on CRU-minus contracts. So I guess those -- a few years back, we just started hearing about these for the first time, and I guess it caused a lot of problems in the market because it kind of created a negative feedback loop with
componenttext: I have a question for you on CRU-minus contracts. So I guess those -- a few years back, we just started hearing about these for the first time, and I guess it caused a lot of problems in the market because it kind of created a negative feedback loop with pricing. And I thought that they went away, but then I was actually talking to some steel buyers in the last few months, and they were talking about having to compete with CRU-minus again. So I was just wondering if you can give an update. Like, are these a big factor in the market again? Has that changed much over the last few years? And how is that influencing things right now?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Clearly, CRU-minus drips in and drips out depending upon how the market conditions are. And right now, we've heard the same things that you have heard, that there are some companies out there offering CRU-minus contracts again. But I want to be real clear
componenttext: Clearly, CRU-minus drips in and drips out depending upon how the market conditions are. And right now, we've heard the same things that you have heard, that there are some companies out there offering CRU-minus contracts again. But I want to be real clear about this. We do not do that. We don't think it's a good business practice, and we take a different approach to it. We think that we sell our product based on quality, service, on-time delivery. And we do what we need to do, I mean, competitive situations, but we do not offer CRU-minus on our sheet business.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good to hear. And then maybe  one other on rebar trade case. So I know you -- the industry tried a trade case on rebar a few years back and -- against Turkey, and the numbers weren't really -- were de minimis. So what about the cases different this
componenttext: Okay, good to hear. And then maybe  one other on rebar trade case. So I know you -- the industry tried a trade case on rebar a few years back and -- against Turkey, and the numbers weren't really -- were de minimis. So what about the cases different this time? I'd know there's been some trade laws passed between now and then. How is that going to influence the outcome this go around?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we feel very positive about the outcome. Okay, frankly, we were disappointed with the outcome last time. But you're right, the recent changes in the trade laws that we had put into effect last year and leveled the playing field at gave us more tools
componenttext: Well, we feel very positive about the outcome. Okay, frankly, we were disappointed with the outcome last time. But you're right, the recent changes in the trade laws that we had put into effect last year and leveled the playing field at gave us more tools that we can better argue these cases and, we believe, more successfully argue these cases. And I will tell you that on rebar in particular, we think that we have a strong case to be made. But frankly, when you look at the results that came out of the last trade case, particularly as they relate to Turkey, there were commitments made at -- during those hearings where Turkey said that they would not increase their imports into the United States. And when you talk about classic hockey stick, these things went off the charts. And the fact that the way that the country acted with their imports into United States on rebar after the trade cases last time, we think, provide tremendous ammunition for us in this case, and we're anxious to prosecute it.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Phil Gibbs with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Phil Gibbs with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I -- you mention a lot of these organic growth projects that you've got going on over the next couple of years. Any sense in terms of the size, Jim, of the CapEx budget this year and next year just to help us with that?
componenttext: I -- you mention a lot of these organic growth projects that you've got going on over the next couple of years. Any sense in terms of the size, Jim, of the CapEx budget this year and next year just to help us with that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've been saying $500 million for this year, but that's actually now going to be up to $635 million on a gross basis because of the reallocation or resetting of our agreements with Encana. But we're also disposing of $135 million of assets. So the n
componenttext: Yes, we've been saying $500 million for this year, but that's actually now going to be up to $635 million on a gross basis because of the reallocation or resetting of our agreements with Encana. But we're also disposing of $135 million of assets. So the net increase is still $500 million in our total PP&E. Next year budget has not been set, but I know that there's a fairly big ask on the table coming up from the divisions. So I would think it's going to probably be at least this strong at this year's net $500 million range.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Aldo Mazzaferro with Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Aldo Mazzaferro with Macquarie.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the LIFO -- a question for Jim on the LIFO. I would have guessed, with scrap down and some of the other commodities down, that you would be going the other way towards LIFO income. Can you comment on what you might expect for the full year or what drov
componenttext: On the LIFO -- a question for Jim on the LIFO. I would have guessed, with scrap down and some of the other commodities down, that you would be going the other way towards LIFO income. Can you comment on what you might expect for the full year or what drove the higher-than-expected LIFO this quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look at where we're at end of the half, we had $46.5 million of expense on a gross basis. So we're targeting $93 million for the year. And based on what we did in the third  quarter, we're now [ph] targeting $141 million for the year, which
componenttext: Yes. So if you look at where we're at end of the half, we had $46.5 million of expense on a gross basis. So we're targeting $93 million for the year. And based on what we did in the third  quarter, we're now [ph] targeting $141 million for the year, which means we going to have somewhere in the neighborhood -- if our estimates today are accurate, in the neighborhood of $35 million of LIFO expense in the fourth quarter. And the reason we bumped up the pace is because of the timing of how -- mainly how the timing of how DRI and pig iron affect us. We buy pig iron on a lagging quarter basis, and it influences our overall cost of DRI as well. And so those 2 commodities came in, deliveries in the third quarter, and it influenced our inventory overall position to a greater extent than we were expecting. So that's changed our outlook for where the balances will be at the end of the year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And John, a question on the -- they might be a little political, but given both candidates are out there with pretty massive comments on infrastructure, one bigger than the other, and I know Trump had Miko [ph] on his team, and I'm wondering wheth
componenttext: Got it. And John, a question on the -- they might be a little political, but given both candidates are out there with pretty massive comments on infrastructure, one bigger than the other, and I know Trump had Miko [ph] on his team, and I'm wondering whether you view one candidate or the other as more beneficial to infrastructure spending and whether you also would expect either candidate to come out with something that could be seen as, if again, early in their tenure.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just going to make a general comment to say that we are really pleased that both sides of the aisle, both candidates and both political parties, are finally understanding the importance of fair and balanced trade. And we're really excited about that.
componenttext: I'm just going to make a general comment to say that we are really pleased that both sides of the aisle, both candidates and both political parties, are finally understanding the importance of fair and balanced trade. And we're really excited about that. Whichever candidate that gets in, we hope that they live up to the campaign promises they made, to recognize the importance of enforcing our trade laws. I will also build on the second part of your question. Both candidates have spoken about the need for infrastructure in the United States. And I will tell you, to me personally, I'm -- as you know, I come from New York. I was in New York a few weeks ago. The conditions on the highways and bridges in New York are deplorable. It's an embarrassment to the United States of America. And when you look at some the estimates that are out there today by different agencies that rate the bridges, rate the roads, so they're talking about a need of spending almost $3 trillion over the next 5 years just to get them up to a B or a B+ level. Think about that amount. That's tremendous. It's long overdue. I hope both candidates or whichever candidate -- excuse me, with -- each of the candidates, whichever one gets in, lives up to their commitments, both on infrastructure and on maintaining the strong enforcement of our trade laws. And that goes not only for the presidency but for Congress also.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll be watching.
componenttext: We'll be watching.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: And John, of the assets that you have not operating today, the utilization rate not at 100%, would you say it's there -- that the ones that are not at full capacity are mostly the construction-related steels?

componenttext: As a general statement, yes.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just conclude by saying to our Nucor family, our customers, our shareholders and our teammates, thank you. Thank you for your business. Thank you for your support. To our teammates, thank you for your hard work that you do every day. Your con
componenttext:
Well, let me just conclude by saying to our Nucor family, our customers, our shareholders and our teammates, thank you. Thank you for your business. Thank you for your support. To our teammates, thank you for your hard work that you do every day. Your contributions have led us to the position of strength that we enjoy today and ensure a bright future for all of us. And most importantly, to my teammates, thank you for doing it safely. 
Thanks for your interest in Nucor. Have a great day.

componenttext: And ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude today's conference. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Third Quarter of 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements t
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Third Quarter of 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future events will not affect their accuracy. More information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Qs, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's websites. 
The forward-looking statements made in this conference call only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Ferriola, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. We appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team, Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias, and our other Executive Vice Pr
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call. We appreciate your interest in Nucor. 
With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team, Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias, and our other Executive Vice Presidents: Jim Darsey, Ladd Hall, Ray Napolitan, Joe Stratman, Dave Sumoski and Chad Utermark. 
In addition to his leadership of our raw materials business, Joe Stratman has recently taken on additional responsibilities as Nucor's Chief Digital Officer. Joe's assignment is to lead the development and implementation of an enterprise-wide information system to collect, analyze and distribute commercial, financial and management data. The objectives are twofold: to drive continual improvement in our decision-making and to provide our customers with world-class business-to-business tools that increase the overall value proposition Nucor provides them. 
The leadership team in Charlotte would like to thank everyone on our Nucor, Harris Steel, David J. Joseph, Duferdofin, NuMit, Steel Technologies and Skyline Steel teams for working together to build a safer, stronger and more profitable Nucor. You are the reason our company is thriving in these challenging steel market conditions and will continue to thrive in the years ahead. Thank you. 
Our teammates at Duferdofin-Nucor, our long products steelmaking joint venture in Italy, provide a great example of how we respond to adverse market conditions. Leveraging significant improvements in cost and product mix, they have increased volume and market share in the very challenging and oversupplied European long product markets. As a result, the Duferdofin-Nucor team has achieved a positive EBITDA for the past 12 consecutive months and a positive operating profit for the last 4 months. They should feel very proud of their accomplishments as they continue their unrelenting drive for continual improvement and a brighter future. We are very grateful to have them as members of the Nucor team. 
We also want to extend a very warm welcome to the newest members of the Nucor family, our Nucor Steel Longview team at our recently acquired specialty plate mill in Texas. Nucor is very proud and very excited to have you on board. 
Our Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias, will now review Nucor's third quarter performance and financial position. Following those comments, I will update you on the execution of our strategy for long-term, profitable growth. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Third quarter of 2016 earnings of $0.84 per diluted share were just below our guidance range of $0.85 to $0.90 per diluted share. However, relative to our guidance, our third quarter results included a larger-than-expected LIFO charge that d
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Third quarter of 2016 earnings of $0.84 per diluted share were just below our guidance range of $0.85 to $0.90 per diluted share. However, relative to our guidance, our third quarter results included a larger-than-expected LIFO charge that decreased our quarterly earnings by $0.08 per diluted share. Third quarter earnings were also reduced by approximately $0.04 per diluted share for the net impact of onetime items. These included expenses for settlement of legal issues as well as a net gain related to asset valuation adjustments. 
The improvement in earnings in the third quarter compared to second quarter was due to improved performance at our sheet mills and our direct reduced iron, or DRI, raw materials facilities. The sheet mills experienced improved margins under contract sales, which are priced on a lag basis. The DRI plants experienced improved transfer pricing of the DRI they sold during the quarter to our steel mills. 
Overall market conditions were very challenging during the third quarter. That was clearly evidenced by a decline in our steel mills segment's capacity utilization rate to 71% in the third quarter from 83% in the second quarter. Third quarter total steel mill tons shipped decreased by 12% from the second quarter 2016. 
Our tax rate can be confusing due to the impact of profits from noncontrolling interests. Excluding profits belonging to our business partners, the effective tax rate was approximately 32.8% for the third quarter and 32.9% for the first 9 months of 2016. 
Nucor's financial position remains strong. Our gross debt-to-capital ratio was 35% at the close of the third quarter. Cash and short-term investments total approximately $2.3 billion, which compares with total debt outstanding of $4.4 billion. Nucor's strong liquidity position also includes our $1.5 billion unsecured revolving credit facility, which remains undrawn. The facility does not mature until April 2021. 
Nucor holds the highest credit ratings of any North American-headquartered steel producer. 
During third quarter, we restructured our natural gas supply agreements with Encana. Low-cost natural gas is critical to the long-term success of Nucor's raw materials strategy. The restructuring ensures that our Louisiana DRI plant has a secure and low-cost supply of natural gas for decades into the future. In turn, DRI gives Nucor the flexibility to optimize the mix and, most importantly, our metallic input costs. Iron units represent more than half of the total costs of our Steelmaking Operations. Just as important, a secure and low-cost supply of high-quality iron units, such as DRI, supports our growth strategy of moving up the value chain into more demanding steel applications. We expect constraints in the supply and cost of higher-quality scrap to grow in the years ahead. 
Here is a recap of the major elements of the restructuring. Nucor purchased 49% of Encana's leasehold interests covering approximately 54,000 acres in the South Piceance Basin. Nucor and Encana terminated 2 Carry and Earning drilling agreements entered into in 2010 and 2012. Nucor also sold to Encana its 50% equity interest in Hunter Ridge gas gathering and processing assets located in the North Piceance Basin. 
The benefits of the new structure are significant. I will outline the top 4. 
First, the leasehold interest provides Nucor full discretion on its participation in all future capital investment. Our decision to invest in any drilling is independent of other leasehold partners. 
Second, by canceling the Carry and Earning drilling agreements, Nucor has eliminated all future Carry cost premiums and contingent liabilities associated with these contracts. That improves Nucor's capital flexibility and should result in lower future drilling costs. .
Three, Nucor owns a tangible asset, the acreage interest, rather than contractual rights. 
Four, Nucor's acreage interest is expected to be able to meet the current gas usage for all of our steel mills and our DRI facility in Louisiana for decades into the future. 
The net result of these transactions is a lower-cost and more flexible hedge against higher natural gas costs for our Louisiana DRI facility and our core Steelmaking Operations. 
Earnings in the fourth quarter of 2016 are expected to decrease notably compared to the third quarter. The 2 most significant challenges are expected to be downward contract pricing resets at our sheet mills and the impact of lower iron units pricing at our raw materials segment. Beyond these near-term issues, we see a number of positive factors that should benefit the steel markets moving into 2017: steel service center inventories are low, residential construction is robust while nonresidential construction activity is expected to continue its slow but steady pace of improvement, trends in U.S. employment and consumer spending remain healthy, more vigorous enforcement of trade laws has begun to reduce the flow of illegally traded imports into the U.S. 
We are confident that Nucor's significant competitive advantages and highly flexible business model will allow our team to continue to execute on our proven strategies for delivering profitable, long-term growth and attractive returns to Nucor shareholders. Thank you for your interest in our company. 
John?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Nucor's strategy for profitable growth is working. We can see the payoff even in the challenging markets of the current prolonged downturn. It is evident in our strong cash flow generation and our industry-leading returns on capital. Most imp
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Nucor's strategy for profitable growth is working. We can see the payoff even in the challenging markets of the current prolonged downturn. It is evident in our strong cash flow generation and our industry-leading returns on capital. Most importantly, it is positioning Nucor to deliver higher highs in profitability during the inevitable cyclical upturn. 
We are executing on our long-term growth strategy by leveraging Nucor's 5 drivers to profitable growth. The 5 drivers are: one, strengthen our position as a low-cost producer; two, achieve market leadership positions in every product line in our portfolio; three, move up the value chain by expanding our capabilities to produce higher-quality, higher-margin products; four, expand and leverage our downstream channels to market to increase our steel mills' baseload volume, especially in weak markets; and five, achieve commercial excellence to complement our traditional operational strength. 
I will now update you on highlights of the recent progress implementing our strategy for profitable growth. 
In August, we completed the acquisition of Joy Global's steel plate mill in Longview, Texas, for approximately $29 million. Annual melting capacity
[Audio Gap]
is booking orders at levels exceeding our expectations. The mill has already doubled its production rate since completion of the acquisition. We are very excited about the opportunities for profitable, long-term growth Nucor Steel Longview offers our plate business. 
In September, we announced an agreement to acquire Independence Tube Corporation. Independence Tube is the second largest U.S. producer of hollow structural section, or HSS, steel tubing. Annual production is about 600,000 tons from 4 facilities in Illinois and Alabama. HSS steel tubing is predominantly used in nonresidential construction. The purchase price is $435 million or approximately 6x average EBITDA over the 2013 to 2015 period. 
Independence Tube is a natural fit with Nucor and our strategy for profitable growth. Our companies' cultures are very similar, sharing key values such as continual improvement, pay for performance and the way we value our team members. Two other very important criteria we apply in evaluating acquisition opportunities are being a low-cost producer and holding a market leadership position. And like Nucor, they operate efficient manufacturing facilities with a highly variable cost structure. Independence Tube will also be a value-added channel to market for Nucor's hot-rolled sheet steel. It's worth noting that the Independence Tube plants are located in close proximity to Nucor's sheet mills in Alabama, Indiana and Kentucky. 
Nucor is already North America's most comprehensive supplier of steel solutions to the construction and infrastructure markets. We hold leadership positions in beams, bar, plate, steel H-piling and pipe piling manufacturing and distribution as well as joists, decking, metal buildings and rebar fabrication. The addition of HSS steel tubing to our product portfolio will further differentiate Nucor from our steel competitors and our ability to take care of our customers. 
We are looking forward to welcoming the Independence Tube team to the Nucor family as our newest growth platform. Closing of this acquisition is expected around the end of October. 
A second major growth initiative was announced in September: plans to build a specialty cold-rolling complex at our Arkansas sheet steel mill. This facility will cost an estimated $230 million. It is expected to be operational in about 2 years. Annual capacity will be approximately 500,000 tons. This investment supports our strategy of moving up the value chain and growing our participation in the automotive market. The Arkansas Specialty Cold Mill Complex will expand our Sheet Mill Group's capabilities to include products that we are currently unable to manufacture. The flexible cold mill reduction mill will allow us to cold-reduce to both lighter gauge and much higher strength levels to meet our customers' lightweighting goals. The upgraded batch anneal shop will include the ultra-high-temperature capability required for production of motor lamination steels with electrical properties previously only obtainable by non-oriented and silicon steels. The Specialty Cold Mill Complex will also broaden the automotive capability of our galvanizing lines at our Alabama and South Carolina sheet mills. 
Our Nucor-Yamato structural steel mill team is on track with the expansion of their value-added product offerings. Shipments of the recently introduced wider-sheet piling sections have increased 2.5-fold through the first 9 months of 2016 compared to the year ago period. 2 of the 4 new sections have been commercialized with the remaining 2 sections to be commissioned by the end of the first quarter of 2017. 
Nucor-Yamato has also begun trial production of its new high-strength, low-alloy beams utilizing the recently installed Quench and Self-Tempering technology. We expect to complete trials across the entire range of these ASTM grade A913 structural sections during the first half of 2017. Nucor-Yamato will be the sole North American producer of high-strength, low-alloy beams. 
Nucor's SBQ bar mill group achieved significant new value-added product milestones in the third quarter. Our Memphis SBQ mill shipped its first annealed and quench and tempered bars utilizing the heat-treating equipment installed earlier this year. With this new value-added capability, Memphis aims to grow its participation in a number of markets, including energy, agriculture and mining. Our Nebraska SBQ mill started up its new coil conveyor system that yields significant quality improvements. This will allow Nebraska to move up the value chain in coil applications for such markets as automotive fasteners and oil and gas. 
These are just some of the exciting initiatives being taken throughout Nucor to drive profitable growth. 
Let me conclude with some comments on the greatest challenge facing the steel industry: global steel overcapacity resulting from the trade-distorting practices of some governments. The message is simple. Significant progress is being made, but there is still a tremendous amount of work to be done. The recent affirmative final determinations in the 3 flat-rolled steel antidumping duty and countervailing duty cases were an important step forward. However, many other products require trade enforcement action, including pending cases addressing illegally traded imports of rebar and cut-to-length plate. At the same time, decisive action is needed to deal with efforts by foreign producers to circumvent duties by routing products through third-party countries. One notable example is China circumventing cold-rolled and coated flat-rolled steel duties by shipping product through Vietnam. 
Nucor embraces free and fair competition. With our culture's focus on continual improvement and technological innovation, Nucor thrives in a marketplace where winners are determined by real economic advantage, not advantages derived by artificial or illegal means. 
For this reason, Nucor will continue to be proactive and aggressive in pursuing effective and timely enforcement of our nation's trade laws. We owe nothing less than that to our customers, our employees and our shareholders. 
Challenges clearly remain for the global steel industry. But for a company such as Nucor, one that is in a unique position of strength and has a proven ability to execute its strategy for profitable growth, these are also times of great opportunity. That is why I'm absolutely confident that Nucor's best years are still ahead of us. 
We would now be happy to answer your questions.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: So looking and understanding your expectations for the fourth quarter, as you laid out in this morning's release, how would you characterize just today your inbound order rates versus, say, 2 weeks ago or even last month? Are there any signs of buyers' appetites increasing or their willingness to pay higher prices starting to emerge even on the margin?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at the order entry rates, particularly in our sheet products, over the last couple of weeks, we have seen an uptick. This is not unexpected. It's a typical annual order rate entry patterns that we see. Towards the end of the third quarte
componenttext: Well, if you look at the order entry rates, particularly in our sheet products, over the last couple of weeks, we have seen an uptick. This is not unexpected. It's a typical annual order rate entry patterns that we see. Towards the end of the third quarter since -- towards the middle of the third quarter, you start to see order entry slack, people beginning to look at year-end inventories. This year, when you looked at the  third quarter, people saw scrap pricing starting to decline that also caused them slow down on their order entry rates. But then as they get into the latter part of the third quarter, the end of the quarter, going to the beginning of the fourth quarter, we would expect we see order entry rate picking up in anticipation of a -- receiving the tonnage in the beginning of the new year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. Let me ask then. You've been very active on M&A, on the investment front, as you went over. Should we expect more from you? As we look over the next 6 months, is this the current price decline in steel? Is that dislodge the assets tha
componenttext: That's very helpful. Let me ask then. You've been very active on M&A, on the investment front, as you went over. Should we expect more from you? As we look over the next 6 months, is this the current price decline in steel? Is that dislodge the assets that you've been interested in? And barring that, what would be your sense of potential for any substantial buyback or lift in the dividend?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we -- as we always say, we don't comment on anything specific. But clearly, our financial position is very strong. Our cash generation from operations are very strong. Now we have the ability to go after targets that we think will bring long-term, p
componenttext: Well, we -- as we always say, we don't comment on anything specific. But clearly, our financial position is very strong. Our cash generation from operations are very strong. Now we have the ability to go after targets that we think will bring long-term, profitable growth and -- to our company and a great return to our -- for our shareholders. So we're always on the lookout for opportunities. And then of course, as we've said many times in the past, if we don't see any opportunities that are out there that we think will bring value to our company and we have an excess of cash on hand, we'll always look at the -- we'll look at the possibility of share back -- buyback or, in one form or another, returning the cash to our shareholders. But of course, our first priority is always long-term, profitable growth through investment when the opportunities present themselves.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Curt Woodworth with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Curt Woodworth with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, when you look at your volume performance in the sheet mill this quarter, it was fairly similar from a utilization rate basis as last quarter -- I'm sorry, in the year ago quarter when you were facing pretty severe import pressure as well as a relati
componenttext: John, when you look at your volume performance in the sheet mill this quarter, it was fairly similar from a utilization rate basis as last quarter -- I'm sorry, in the year ago quarter when you were facing pretty severe import pressure as well as a relatively choppy nonres market. Today, you have the trade case victories, you've got nonres improving, auto is relatively more resilient. And you have the fact that a lot of the U.S. blast furnaces have ceded a fair amount of hot band market share to the EAF. So I'm just curious, what is your take on that? And I guess from a macro basis, what are you seeing that maybe is particularly weaker than you thought at the exit of last quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start by making a few comments on your question. When we look at automotive, we see it just about the same as last year. We don't see it significantly better. In terms of nonresidential construction, we really don't see it much more improved
componenttext: Well, let me start by making a few comments on your question. When we look at automotive, we see it just about the same as last year. We don't see it significantly better. In terms of nonresidential construction, we really don't see it much more improved than last year. In fact, if you go through the costs of the year, particularly towards the middle of 2016, there was actually a decrease in the activity on nonresidential construction. So we don't see much of a pop from that side either. And although we have been very successful in our trade cases, particularly on sheet, we're really just beginning to see the impact of that. And frankly, we do see imports going down, but still they represent a very large portion of our total market share. We continue -- that's why we continue to fight the battle, and we will continue to fight and be successful in the battle against illegal imports. So we're just beginning to see some of that impact. But let me address another point of the capacity utilization. Particularly as it applies here at Nucor. We've talked many times about our commitment to pursuing higher-value products, and we're going to continue to do that. We believe that having improved margins and profitability is more important than utilization. And as we've said in the past, as you move -- as you change your product mix to those higher-value, higher-quality products, that usually has an impact on your run rates in the mills. A great example would be either the wide project at our Berkeley facility or the wider piling sections at our Nucor-Yamato facility. Both of those have reduced the run rate significantly although they're much more profitable products. So we don't get so hung up on utilization. Now we've mentioned on the last call, and I'll mention it again, that we intend to, at the end of the year, take a look at how our product mix has shifted over the last several years. It's been forever since we adjusted the denominator in this calculation, and we're going to take a hard look at how our product mix shift has impacted our...

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Capacity.
componenttext: Capacity.

componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And then just with respect to trade and the Vietnam petition, it seems like there's a prevalent view that processing or cold-rolling material in Vietnam doesn't fundamentally change the nature -- or does fundamentally change what the product is. Can you just kind of comment on the nuance of that and how you think the Department of Commerce is going to treat that issue specifically?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not going to go into too much detail as this is an ongoing investigation and there has not been a final determination on this. We feel strongly, very strongly, that our position is a strong one. It's clear to us. Our opinion is it's clearly an i
componenttext: Well, I'm not going to go into too much detail as this is an ongoing investigation and there has not been a final determination on this. We feel strongly, very strongly, that our position is a strong one. It's clear to us. Our opinion is it's clearly an issue of circumvention. You can look at the percentage of imports of cold-rolled product from China into Vietnam and seen the tremendous jump over the last 6 months. It's clear what's going on. And we think that particularly, when you look at the political environment today, where both sides of the aisle is a recognition of what's going on around the world with illegal trade, I feel and our team feels very confident that we'll be successful in the circumvention case.

That's my first question.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me -- I'll start off then I'll hand it over to Chad, our Executive Vice President in charge of our plate business. But just as a general comment, obviously we're not going to speak about any pricing specific, but the plate market has been very c
componenttext: Well, let me -- I'll start off then I'll hand it over to Chad, our Executive Vice President in charge of our plate business. But just as a general comment, obviously we're not going to speak about any pricing specific, but the plate market has been very challenging. It's been a tough year on plate. It doesn't look like it's getting much better towards the end of the year. We can go market by market, but there's no strong market right now that we would point to say that we're going to see a big pop in pricing. I would make one comment and then, Chad, you can build on this. When you look at the pricing levels in plate today, personally I feel they're just not sustainable over the long term. But Chad, would you like to add anything to that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, John. I agree, the plate market is very challenged currently. Your assessment of where plate prices are compared to hot roll is true that being below hot-rolled prices, which they are now according to CRU, is something that we have rarely see
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, John. I agree, the plate market is very challenged currently. Your assessment of where plate prices are compared to hot roll is true that being below hot-rolled prices, which they are now according to CRU, is something that we have rarely seen over the history of pricing. So I do not believe that's sustainable long term. There is some fundamental demand challenges out there in the plate market right now. And we did announce recently a plate price increase. That was late last week, and we are monitoring that situation at this time.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: In light of the fact that met coal is all of a sudden back to the reason that you, I think, started to invest in DRI, I wanted to get a sense of, if we were to believe that scrap moves with met, are we looking at it again returning to that advantage that you were hoping for in DRI? And how are you thinking about what hedge that might offer you in a strong met coal environment into 2017?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, there are many -- there are several things that scrap tends to be -- scrap pricing tends to be linked to. Certainly, one of the most important is volume. Now as the build business picks up and people have a greater demand for scrap, the pri
componenttext: Well, clearly, there are many -- there are several things that scrap tends to be -- scrap pricing tends to be linked to. Certainly, one of the most important is volume. Now as the build business picks up and people have a greater demand for scrap, the price of scrap goes up. And there's also a linkage, as you mentioned, to coking coal, and we expect to see some small increase as a result of that. But as we see scrap right now, scrap is a pretty low number. We think it's probably at the bottom. We -- as we look out for the rest of the year, we might see a small incremental increase but nothing substantial. Joe, anything you want to add to that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you really covered it, John. The -- as we head into the winter, there's always going to be a seasonality issue or potential on scrap flow. Northern scrap yards need to close down or slow down, et cetera. But any strength that gives us is proba
componenttext: No, I think you really covered it, John. The -- as we head into the winter, there's always going to be a seasonality issue or potential on scrap flow. Northern scrap yards need to close down or slow down, et cetera. But any strength that gives us is probably just seasonal. And ultimately, it'll follow the demand in the steel mills.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now I will take it away from scrap for a minute and say that as you look at what's going to happen, as these companies are going into next year's contract for buying coking coal, that we believe that there will be an increase based upon the current spot p
componenttext: Now I will take it away from scrap for a minute and say that as you look at what's going to happen, as these companies are going into next year's contract for buying coking coal, that we believe that there will be an increase based upon the current spot price. And obviously, on final product, we see that that's going to put us in a more competitive position than we were when coking coal was at half the price it is today.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Timna. This is Joe Stratman. Clearly, that's true. I mean, obviously, one of the major cost components of either pig iron or DRI is what form of reductant do you use and what reductant that -- what cost that reductant is at. So if you compare the cos
componenttext: Yes, Timna. This is Joe Stratman. Clearly, that's true. I mean, obviously, one of the major cost components of either pig iron or DRI is what form of reductant do you use and what reductant that -- what cost that reductant is at. So if you compare the cost of coking coal as you reducted in a pig iron environment versus natural gas in a DRI environment, you can clearly see some cost differential depending on where those 2 commodities are moving.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Timna, if I can just add something quickly. And that is, this is exactly why we moved forward with the DRI strategy. We look at it, as we've talked about many times, this is a hedge. It gives us the flexibility, gives us balance. And as the cost of ra
componenttext: And Timna, if I can just add something quickly. And that is, this is exactly why we moved forward with the DRI strategy. We look at it, as we've talked about many times, this is a hedge. It gives us the flexibility, gives us balance. And as the cost of raw materials change, and the cost of raw materials in steelmaking represent more than 50% of the cost of the product, this gives us a tremendous advantage as things shift. And given our DRI and our D.J. Joseph Company, the ability to buy pig iron or HBI when it makes sense, our DRI facilities, be able to buy scrap internationally, these are the kinds of things when you have these kind of movements, as we've seen today with coking cold, that really point to the value of our long-term raw material strategy.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's another competitor, and we've never shied away from competition. As long as it's fair and legal, we love it. And we're confident that we can take it on without having an impact upon our business. Now certainly, it's going to hurt the market. Certainl
componenttext: It's another competitor, and we've never shied away from competition. As long as it's fair and legal, we love it. And we're confident that we can take it on without having an impact upon our business. Now certainly, it's going to hurt the market. Certainly, that's going to have an influence on the market. But given what we've been doing, particularly in the Southeast and in the markets that we have been targeting, as we move up the value chain, certainly it's going to be a while before they can move up into the same areas that -- or products that we're producing, particularly the high-strengths, advanced high-strengths and the automotive kind of markets that we're moving into. So you're right, as we move away from more and more -- away from the, well, commodity grades, we'll have less of an impact. I'll also point out to you, Timna, you heard in our script about our Specialty Cold Mill Complex that's going into Hickman. I might point out that Hickman's -- I don't know how many miles but not that many miles away from Big River Steel. And we are confident that the unique mill equipment that we're putting in there is going to give us an ability to produce products that we can't produce today, but products that certainly Big River can't produce today. And we think that, that will give us another edge over them as they come up with their more commoditized products.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. And if I could slip one last one in on that same vein, I mean, if we expect, let's say, hypothetically auto is flat going forward from here, is there a case to be made that Nucor could continue to increase its share there? And can you quantify that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, we're very confident. We -- first of all, just to comment on your statement, we agree. We think that going into 2017, autos will be basically flat. We don't see it going up. It might go down a little bit, but we don't see it changing significantly
componenttext: Listen, we're very confident. We -- first of all, just to comment on your statement, we agree. We think that going into 2017, autos will be basically flat. We don't see it going up. It might go down a little bit, but we don't see it changing significantly. And even in that environment, we will continue to grow our market share not only in the types of products that we can produce that go into automotive, but frankly in the number of automotive companies that have an interest in doing business with us. As we've said many times, our target is to reach 2 million tons by 2018. Today, we're somewhere around 1.4 million, 1.45 million, in that range. And the team here will tell you that our next target is 3 million tons by 2021. I will tell you that our next target is 3 million tons by 2020. And frankly, the JV that we -- you've heard us talk about in the script, the JV with JFE is going to be a big boost not only in that particular project or on the galvanizing side, but, frankly, the recognition that Nucor has achieved by being picked as a partner with JFE clearly the premier automotive steel producer in the world will put to bed finally this argument about whether or not automotive-grade steels can be made in an electric arc furnace shop, particular one that has Nucor name on the front of the facility.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question for you on CRU-minus contracts. So I guess those -- a few years back, we just started hearing about these for the first time, and I know they caused a lot of problems in the market because it kind of created a negative feedback loop with
componenttext: I have a question for you on CRU-minus contracts. So I guess those -- a few years back, we just started hearing about these for the first time, and I know they caused a lot of problems in the market because it kind of created a negative feedback loop with pricing. And I thought that they went away, but then I was actually talking to some steel buyers in the last few months, and they were talking about having to compete with CRU-minus again. So I was just wondering if you can give an update. Like, are these a big factor in the market again? Has that changed much over the last few years? And how is that influencing things right now?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Clearly, CRU-minus drips in and drips out depending upon how the market conditions are. And right now, we've heard the same things that you have heard, that there are some companies out there offering CRU-minus contracts again. But I want to be real clear
componenttext: Clearly, CRU-minus drips in and drips out depending upon how the market conditions are. And right now, we've heard the same things that you have heard, that there are some companies out there offering CRU-minus contracts again. But I want to be real clear about this. We do not do that. We don't think it's a good business practice, and we take a different approach to it. We think that we sell our product based on quality, service, on-time delivery. And we do what we need to do to meet competitive situations, but we do not offer CRU-minus on our sheet business.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good to hear. And then maybe one other on rebar trade case. So I know you -- the industry tried a trade case on rebar a few years back and -- against Turkey, and the numbers weren't really -- were de minimis. So what about the case is different this
componenttext: Okay, good to hear. And then maybe one other on rebar trade case. So I know you -- the industry tried a trade case on rebar a few years back and -- against Turkey, and the numbers weren't really -- were de minimis. So what about the case is different this time? I'd know there's been some trade laws passed between now and then. How is that going to influence the outcome this go around?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we feel very positive about the outcome. Okay, frankly, we were disappointed with the outcome last time. But you're right, the recent changes in the trade laws that we had put into effect last year and leveled the playing field at gave us more tools
componenttext: Well, we feel very positive about the outcome. Okay, frankly, we were disappointed with the outcome last time. But you're right, the recent changes in the trade laws that we had put into effect last year and leveled the playing field at gave us more tools that we can better argue these cases and, we believe, more successfully argue these cases. And I will tell you that on rebar in particular, we think that we have a strong case to be made. But frankly, when you look at the results that came out of the last trade case, particularly as they relate to Turkey, there were commitments made at -- during those hearings where Turkey said that they would not increase their imports into the United States. And when you talk about classic hockey stick, these things went off the charts. And the fact that the way that the country acted with their imports into United States on rebar after the trade cases last time, we think, provide tremendous ammunition for us in this case, and we're anxious to prosecute it.

componenttext: Yes, we've been saying $500 million for this year, but that's actually now going to be up to $635 million on a gross basis because of the reallocation or resetting of our agreements with Encana. But we're also disposing of $135 million of assets. So the net increase is still $500 million in our total PP&E. Next year budget has not been set, but I know that there's a fairly big ask on the table coming up from the divisions. So I would think it's going to probably be at least as strong as this year's net $500 million range.

componenttext: On the LIFO -- a question for Jim on the LIFO. I would have guessed, with scrap down and some of the other commodities down, that you would be going the other way towards LIFO income. Can you comment on what you might expect for the full year or what drove the higher-than-expected LIFO this quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look at where we're at end of the half, we had $46.5 million of expense on a gross basis. So we're targeting $93 million for the year. And based on what we did in the third quarter, we're now [ph] targeting $141 million for the year, which
componenttext: Yes. So if you look at where we're at end of the half, we had $46.5 million of expense on a gross basis. So we're targeting $93 million for the year. And based on what we did in the third quarter, we're now [ph] targeting $141 million for the year, which means we going to have somewhere in the neighborhood -- if our estimates today are accurate, in the neighborhood of $35 million of LIFO expense in the fourth quarter. And the reason we bumped up the pace is because of the timing of how -- mainly how the timing of how DRI and pig iron affect us. We buy pig iron on a lagging quarter basis, and it influences our overall cost of DRI as well. And so those 2 commodities came in, deliveries in the third quarter, and it influenced our inventory overall position to a greater extent than we were expecting. So that's changed our outlook for where the balances will be at the end of the year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And John, a question on the -- they might be a little political, but given both candidates are out there with pretty massive comments on infrastructure, one bigger than the other, and I know Trump has DiMicco on his team, and I'm wondering whether
componenttext: Got it. And John, a question on the -- they might be a little political, but given both candidates are out there with pretty massive comments on infrastructure, one bigger than the other, and I know Trump has DiMicco on his team, and I'm wondering whether you view one candidate or the other as more beneficial to infrastructure spending and whether you also would expect either candidate to come out with something that could be significant early in their tenure.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just going to make a general comment to say that we are really pleased that both sides of the aisle, both candidates and both political parties, are finally understanding the importance of fair and balanced trade. And we're really excited about that.
componenttext: I'm just going to make a general comment to say that we are really pleased that both sides of the aisle, both candidates and both political parties, are finally understanding the importance of fair and balanced trade. And we're really excited about that. Whichever candidate that gets in, we hope that they live up to the campaign promises they made, to recognize the importance of enforcing our trade laws. I will also build on the second part of your question. Both candidates have spoken about the need for infrastructure in the United States. And I will tell you, to me personally, I'm -- as you know, I come from New York. I was in New York a few weeks ago. The conditions on the highways and bridges in New York are deplorable. It's an embarrassment to the United States of America. And when you look at some the estimates that are out there today by different agencies that rate the bridges, rate the roads, so they're talking about a need of spending almost $3 trillion over the next 5 years just to get them up to a B or a B+ level. Think about that amount. That's tremendous. It's long overdue. I hope both candidates or whichever candidate -- excuse me, with -- each of the candidates, whichever one gets in, lives up to their commitments, both on infrastructure and on maintaining the strong enforcement of our trade laws. And that goes not only for the presidency but for Congress also.
